engaged in the purposes of loading and unloading in the conduct of another use
as defined in the Zoning Code on a property. (Ord. 23-38, 8-21-2023)
3-28-4: IMPOSED:
Any person residing or operating within the City who stores any trailer,
semitrailer, or truck tractor, or who causes or permits any of his agents,
employees, lessees, or licensees to store any trailer, semitrailer, or truck
tractor on a semitruck and trailer storage lot within the City shall pay to the
City the tax described in this chapter. (Ord. 23-38, 8-21-2023)
3-28-5: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall own and operate a Truck and Semi-trailer Storage Lot unless the
property is property zoned for the specified use and a valid operating license
is issued by the Community and Economic Development Department for the specific
Truck and Semi-Trailer Storage Lot. This license is renewable on June 1 each
year. There shall be no more than five (5) Truck and semi-trailer Storage Lot
licenses issued by the City at any given time. (Ord. 23-38, 8-21-2023)
3-28-6: APPLICATION:
All complete applications for Truck and Semi-trailer Storage Lots shall be
submitted in writing to the Community and Economic Development Department. The
application shall include the following information and documentation:
   A.   A new application for a license shall include a parking lot stripe plan
that conforms to the requirements of the Zoning Code Section 4.217.C.1.
   B.   The number of approved parking spaces for trucks, trailers, and semi-
trailers.
   C.   The name and home address of the applicant.
   D.   The name and address of the business.
   E.   The names and addresses of all officers of a firm, partnership, or
corporation.
   F.   Whether the property is owned or leased by the applicant, and if
leased, for what duration and purpose.
   G.   The name and address of the lessor.
   H.   The applicant shall submit evidence of ownership (deed or title policy)
or a valid lease, and shall file a copy thereof with the City.
   I.   A copy of the ordinance approving the conditional use for the truck and
semi-trailer storage lot shall be submitted with the completed application.
(Ord. 23-38, 8-21-2023)
3-28-7: RATE AND VIOLATIONS:
   A.   The tax payable under this chapter shall be seven hundred and fifty
hundred dollars ($750.00) per parking space per year beginning on June 1,
2024.The owner or operator of the truck and semi-trailer storage lot shall also
be responsible for obtaining any and all applicable license(s) required by City
code to operate within the City. This tax is payable on or before June 1 of
each year.
   B.   Failure to comply with this section shall result in a minimum fine of
two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00), each day of noncompliance shall be considered a separate and
distinct violation. The City reserves the right to suspend or revoke the
license of owners or operators who are found to have repeatedly violated this
section. (Ord. 23-38, 8-21-2023)
3-28-8: LICENSE STANDARDS, REGULATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS: 
In addition to any other condition or regulations contained in the City Code or
the statutes of the state, the following conditions and regulations shall be
applicable to and shall govern and control truck and semi-trailer storage lots.
   A.   Truck and semi-trailer storage lots shall be completely fenced in
compliance with the Zoning Code and shall have at least one (1) gate for
entering and exiting the property. The gate shall be secured and locked at all
times, except when vehicles or persons are entering or exiting the property.
The owner shall establish and maintain emergency access to the lot by
arrangement with the City of Batavia. A Knox Box provided by the City of
Batavia is required for emergency access to the property.
   B.   Truck and semi-trailer storage lots shall post at all entry gates the
following:
      1.   A minimum sign of 3 feet by 3 feet of white backing with black
lettering with the following information.
         a.   The name and contact information of the owner.
         b.   Authorized leasing agent or management for the lot.
   C.   Concrete or asphalt for pavement, curbing and gutter shall be installed
on all truck and semi-trailer storage lot parking areas and drive aisles.
Gravel is a prohibited surface.
   D.   No repair work may be performed on any truck, trailer, semi-trailer, or
any vehicle on the property except in an enclosed structure located on truck
and semi-trailer storage lot. This shall not include emergency tire repairs.
   E.   A tow truck facility is prohibited from operating on the same lot of a
truck and semi-trailer storage lot.
   F.   The storage of hazardous materials is prohibited.
   G.   The storage of operating refrigeration trucks or trailers is
prohibited.
   H.   The vertical storage of trailers or containers is prohibited.
   I.   The storage of inoperable motor vehicles and trailers is prohibited.
All motor vehicles and trailers on the lot shall be licensed and registered.
(Ord. 23-38, 8-21-2023)
3-28-9: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Any license for the operation of a truck and semi-trailer storage lot
may be revoked by the Mayor and City Council after a hearing on ten (10) days
written notice to the licensee of such hearing for the following acts, conduct,
or omissions:
      1.   Failure to keep ground surfaces paved as required by the Zoning
Code. Failure to keep and maintain such surfaces of such parking lot and
driveways free from the accumulation of dust, dirt, rubbish, debris, and
litter.
      2.   Parking or permitting nonworking or disabled or inoperative motor
vehicles or abandoned motor vehicles or junked motor vehicles or any other such
similar vehicles to be stored or parked upon such storage lot or to remain on
the storage lot for more than twenty-four (24) hours.
      3.   Making or permitting any material change in the operation, physical
construction or layout of such trailers and semi-trailers storage lot
inconsistent with the licensee’s initial application for the license and such
license without first submitting for approval to and without obtaining approval
from the Community and Economic Development Department for such material
changes.
      4.   Allowing or permitting the use of any trailer and semi-trailer
storage lot to store or park a trailer or semitrailer or any other vehicle for
the purpose of displaying the vehicle for sale.
      5.   Permitting the use of such storage lot as a motor vehicle repair
shop or for the conduct of any other business whatsoever by the licensee or by
any lessee of the licensee, including the vending of tools, wares or
merchandise or services in connection therewith upon such storage lot.
      6.   Violating or knowingly permitting the violation of any City
ordinance or any felony state penal law regarding theft, larceny, the
conversion of any motor vehicle or the operation thereof without the owner’s
consent, or any other crime of moral turpitude whether or not such licensee of
any other person is convicted of such violation.
      7.   Making or permitting the making of any false or misleading
statements or representations or misrepresentations in the application or plat
or drawing accompanying the application.
      8.   The acts or omissions elicited in subsections A.1. through A.8. of
this section shall, in addition of being grounds for revocation of the parking
lot license also be punishable by a fine of no less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750) and may
further be subject to revocation.
(Ord. 23-38, 8-21-2023)
CHAPTER 29
RESTRICTION ON SALE OF KRATOM AND HEMP DERIVED PRODUCTS
SECTION:
3-29-1: Definitions
3-29-2: Sale Of Intoxicating Product
3-29-3: Display
3-29-4: Prohibited Packaging
3-29-5: Signage
3-29-6: Penalty
3-29-7: Exemptions
3-29-1: DEFINITIONS:
HEMP DERIVED PRODUCTS: Any product, material, compound, isomer, acid, salt,
mixture, or preparation used or intended for human consumption that contains or
claims to contain:
   A.   Delta-1 cis or trans tetrahydrocannabinol;
   B.   Delta-6 cis or trans tetrahydrocannabinol, and its optical isomers;
   C.   Delta-3.4 cis or trans tetrahydrocannabinol, and its optical isomers;
   D.   Delta-10 cis or trans tetrahydrocannabinol, and its optical isomers;
   E.   Delta-8 tetrahydrocannabinol acetate 8 ester;
   F.   Delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol acetate 10 ester where the total delta-
9 THC content concentration level is in excess of 0.3% on a dry weight basis or
a total delta-9 THC content in excess of half of a milligram (0.5mg.) per
labeled serving or individual unit or two and a half (2.5) milligrams per
package regardless of the number of labeled servings or individual units
therein;
   G.   Delta-6a,10a tetrahydrocannabinol acetate ester;
   H.   Delta-10 tetrahydrocannabinol acetate ester;
   I.   A product, material, compound, isomer, acid, sale, mixture, or
preparation derived from industrial hemp that was produced as a result of a
chemical process that converted the industrial hemp or a substance contained in
the industrial hemp into Delta-8, Delta-9, Delta-6a, 10a, or Delta-10
tetrahydrocannabinol including their respective acetate esters; and
   J.   Any analog derived therein.
INTOXICATING PRODUCT: Any product, material, compound, isomer, acid, salt,
mixture, or preparation containing kratom or hemp derived products.
INTOXICATING PRODUCT BUSINESS: A person engaged in the sale at retail, giving
away, or delivery with the intent of selling at retail of intoxicating
products.
KRATOM: Any part of the plant Mitragyna speciosa, whether growing or not, and
any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of that
plant, including, but not limited to, mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine.
PERSON: An individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, joint
venture, limited liability company, limited liability partnership, receiver,
executor, trustee, guardian, or other representative appointed by order of any
court.
(Ord. 2025-008, 6-2-2025)
3-29-2: SALE OF INTOXICATING PRODUCT:
   No person and no intoxicating product business or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent, or employee of such business, shall sell, offer
for sale, give away, deliver or distribute any intoxicating products to
individuals unless the individual is twenty-one (21) years old and older.
Before making a sale or delivery of an intoxicating product, an officer,
associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such business shall
demand presentation of adequate written evidence of identity, including,
without limitation, a photograph, and of the fact that the purchaser or
recipient is over the age of twenty-one (21) years. Adequate written evidence
of identity and age shall be satisfied by a document issued by a federal,
state, county, or municipal government, or a subdivision or agency thereof,
including, but not limited to, a motor vehicle operator's license, a
registration certificate issued under the federal selective service act, or an
identification card issued to a member of the armed forces.
(Ord. 2025-008, 6-2-2025)
3-29-3: DISPLAY:
   Display of intoxicating products shall either be behind a sales or service
counter or locked case so that no person may access it without assistance by an
officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of such
intoxicating product business or in a section of the intoxicating product
business where other age restricted twenty-one (21) years and older products
are displayed.
   In the alternative, an intoxicating product business may restrict access to
individuals twenty-one (21) years and older unless accompanied by a parent or
legal guardian who is twenty-one (21) years and older so long as the
intoxicating product business checks for adequate written evidence of identity
and age upon a person's entry into the intoxicating product business and posts
a sign prominently at the entrance of the business which is plainly visible
from the exterior of the business and states:
NOTICE YOU MUST BE AT LEAST 21 YEARS OF AGE TO ENTER PHOTO ID REQUIRED
   The text of such signs must be in red letters on a white background with
letters at least one inch in height.
(Ord. 2025-008, 6-2-2025)
3-29-4: PROHIBITED PACKAGING:
   Packaging of intoxicating products shall not have packaging or labeling
that: 1) resembles trademarked, characteristic or product-specialized packaging
of any commercially available candy, snack, baked good or beverage; or 2)
contains images of food, candy, baked goods, cereal, fruit, beverages, or the
words "candy" or "candies"; or 3) contains images, graphics, features, or
likeness to images, graphics, or features that are popularly used to advertise
to children, such as cartoons, animals, neon colors, celebrities, mascots, or
phrases.
(Ord. 2025-008, 6-2-2025)
3-29-5: SIGNAGE:
   An intoxicating product business which does not restrict access to the
business to individuals twenty-one (21) years and older unless accompanied by a
parent or legal guardian who is twenty-one (21) years and older must post a
sign informing the public of the age restrictions in this article at or near
every display of intoxicating products. Each sign must be plainly visible and
state:
THE SALE OF INTOXICATING PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER 21 YEARS OF AGE IS
PROHIBITED BY LAW.
   The text of such signs must be in red letters on a white background with
letters at least one inch (1") in height.
(Ord. 2025-008, 6-2-2025)
3-29-6: PENALTY:
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall, upon a
finding of guilty, be punished by a fine of up to seven hundred and fifty
dollars ($750) per day. The Local Liquor Commissioner or Mayor has additional
authority to suspend, revoke, and/or fine any City licensed business who is
violating or has violated the provisions of this chapter pursuant to the same
rules and procedures set forth in regard to liquor licenses as provided in
Chapter 3 of this title and tobacco licenses under Chapter 2 of Title 4. Each
day such violation continues constitutes a separate fineable offense. Fines may
be assessed in administrative adjudication and/or through a local ordinance
violation brought in the Circuit Court.
(Ord. 2025-008, 6-2-2025)
3-29-7: EXEMPTIONS:
   Any cannabis business establishments duly licensed under, and in accordance
with, the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act (410 ILCS 130/1, et
seq.) or the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act (410 ILCS 705/1-1, et seq.).
(Ord. 2025-008, 6-2-2025)
TITLE 4
HEALTH AND SANITATION
CHAPTER 1
HEALTH AND DISEASE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-1-1: Report Of Contagious Disease
4-1-2: Spreading Contagion
4-1-3: Quarantine Procedures
4-1-4: Penalty
4-1-1: REPORT OF CONTAGIOUS DISEASE:
Every physician called in to care for or treat a person afflicted with a
contagious or epidemic disease shall make a report of the same to the Health
Officer within twenty four (24) hours after being called in. In case no
physician is in attendance, it shall be the duty of the person in charge of or
having the care of such person to make a report within twenty four (24) hours
from the time the disease is recognized. (1972 Code § 97.001)
4-1-2: SPREADING CONTAGION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or carelessly spread any
contagious disease or to so cause the spread of the same. (1972 Code § 97.015)
4-1-3: QUARANTINE PROCEDURES:
   A.   Board Of Health To Enforce: The Board of Health and Health Officer
shall have charge of the enforcement of reasonable quarantine rules. They shall
have the power and authority to place any premises within which a contagious or
epidemic disease occurs under quarantine, and the Board of Health shall
determine the time when the quarantine ends. (1972 Code § 97.005)
   B.   Fumigation: Premises which have been quarantined in accordance with the
terms of the preceding subsection shall be thoroughly fumigated or otherwise
freed from all risk of contagious disease, under the supervision of the Health
Officer before determining the time when the quarantine ends. (1972 Code §
97.010)
   C.   Deliveries To Quarantined Premises: No person engaged in the delivery
of food or drink intended for human consumption shall enter any premises which
are quarantined because of the existence of a contagious or epidemic disease.
No containers or bottles shall be removed from such premises until the
termination of the quarantine; and no such container which has been left at
such premises during the quarantine shall be placed in use for carrying food or
drink until it has been thoroughly sterilized. (1972 Code § 97.020)
4-1-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Chapter or violating any reasonable
rule of the Board of Health with regard to quarantined premises, or disturbing
or disregarding any notice of quarantine placed by or under the direction of
the Board of Health shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1972 Code § 97.999; amd.
1986 Code)
CHAPTER 2
TOBACCO REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-2-1: Definitions
4-2-2: License Required
4-2-3: Application For License; Fee
4-2-4: Prohibitions Regarding Minors
4-2-5: Vending Machines; Locking Devices
4-2-6: Responsibility For Agents And Employees
4-2-7: Suspension And Revocation Of License
4-2-8: Violations/Penalties
4-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
                             Anything designed, made, or used to smoke, inhale,
                             or otherwise consume a tobacco product or
                             alternative tobacco product, including, but not
ACCESSORIES:                 limited to, pipes, rolling papers, cigarette and
                             electronic cigarette receptacles and holders, and
                             vape apparatus, vape kits, and their component
                             parts, and the like.
                             Any ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT as defined under
                             the Illinois Prevention of Tobacco Use by Minors
ALTERNATIVE TOBACCO PRODUCT: and Sale and Distribution of Tobacco Products Act
                             (720 ILCS 675/1), as amended from time to time,
                             specifically including electronic cigarettes or e-
                             cigarettes.
LICENSE:                     A license issued by the city of Batavia for the
                             retail sale of tobacco products.
LICENSEE:                    The holder of a valid license for the retail sale
                             of tobacco products.
MINOR:                       Any person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
                             Any form of the chemical nicotine, including any
NICOTINE:                    salt or complex, regardless of whether the
                             chemical is naturally or synthetically derived.
                             Any person who sells at retail tobacco products,
TOBACCO DEALER:              tobacco accessories, alternative tobacco products,
                             or alternative tobacco accessories.
TOBACCO PRODUCT:             Any product containing or made from tobacco as
                             defined in the Act.
                             Any mechanical, electric or electronic self
                             service device, which, upon insertion of money,
VENDING MACHINE:             tokens or any other form of payment, dispenses
                             tobacco products. (Ord. 01-22, 10-1-2001; amd.
                             Ord. 19-61, 12-16-2019)
 
(Ord. 01-22, 10-1-2001; amd. Ord. 19-61, 12-16-2019)
4-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell, or offer for sale, at retail, give away, deliver
or to keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away or delivering
tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine products or
accessories within the city without having first obtained a valid tobacco/
alternative nicotine dealer's license from the city for each location in which
tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine products or
accessories are sold. All such licenses must be renewed annually. Such license
shall be in addition to any other license required by this code. (Ord. 01-22,
10-1-2001; amd. Ord. 19-61, 12-16-2019)
4-2-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
   A.   Applications for licenses shall be made in writing to the mayor. No
such license shall be issued to any person who is not at least twenty one (21)
years of age.
   B.   The annual license fee for a tobacco dealer's license shall be fifty
dollars ($50.00), and where vending machines are used for such sale, an
additional fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid for each machine.
   C.   A tobacco dealer's license is nontransferable, provided, however, a new
license will be issued to a tobacco retailer who changes location. (Ord. 01-22,
10-1-2001; amd. Ord. 19-61, 12-16-2019)
4-2-4: PROHIBITIONS REGARDING MINORS:
It shall be unlawful:
   A.   Sales To: For any person, including any licensee, to sell, offer for
sale, give away or deliver tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, or
alternative nicotine products or accessories to any person under the age of
twenty one (21) years.
Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for herein shall be
posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco products,
electronic cigarettes, alternative tobacco products or accessories, and on or
upon every vending machine which offers tobacco products for sale. Each such
sign shall be plainly visible and shall state:
   THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS
   OR ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS AND
   ACCESSORIES TO PERSONS UNDER
   TWENTY-ONE YEARS OF AGE IS
   PROHIBITED BY LAW.
The text of such signs shall be in red letters on white background; said
letters to be at least one inch (1") high.
   B.   Sale By: For any licensee or any officer, associate, member,
representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to engage, employ or permit
any person under eighteen (18) years of age to sell tobacco products,
electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine products or accessories in any
premises.
   C.   Purchase: For any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to
purchase tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine
products and accessories, or to misrepresent their identity or age, or to use
any false or altered identification for the purpose of purchasing tobacco
products, electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine products and
accessories.
   D.   Possession: For any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to
possess any tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine
products and accessories; provided, that the possession by a person under the
age of twenty one (21) years under the direct supervision of the parent or
guardian of such person in the privacy of the parent's or guardian's home shall
not be prohibited. (Ord. 01-22, 10-1-2001; amd. Ord. 19-61, 12-16-2019)
4-2-5: VENDING MACHINES; LOCKING DEVICES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer for sale, give
away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling, giving away or
delivering tobacco products by use of a vending machine unless such vending
machine is equipped with a manual, electric or electronic locking device
controlled by the licensee so as to prevent its operation by persons under the
age of twenty one (21) years.
   B.   Each cigarette vending machine shall be so installed as to be
inaccessible to persons under twenty one (21) years of age. Every vending
machine not installed as to be inaccessible to persons under twenty one (21)
years of age is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. Inaccessibility may be
accomplished either by placement of the machine in a room or area to which
persons under twenty one (21) years of age do not have access or by the
installation of a manual, electric, electronic, or remote control locking
device which can be activated and controlled only by an employee or agent of
the licensees over the age of twenty one (21) on the premises on which such
machine is located, and then only after such employee or agent has verified
that the person desiring to purchase cigarettes is not a person under twenty
one (21) years of age. The cigarette vending machine must be placed at a
distance of a minimum of twenty five feet (25') from any entrance to the
premises and be directly visible by the owner, tenant, or lawful possessor of
the premises, or his or her employees or agents during the operation of such
vending machine.
   C.   Any premises where access by persons under the age of twenty one (21)
years is prohibited by law or premises where the public is generally not
permitted and where vending machines are strictly for the use of employees of
the business located at such premises shall be exempt from the requirements of
this section. (Ord. 01-22, 10-1-2001; amd. Ord. 19-61, 12-16-2019)
4-2-6: RESPONSIBILITY FOR AGENTS AND EMPLOYEES:
Every act or omission of any nature constituting a violation of any provision
of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of
any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such licensee; and such
licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act or omission had
been done or omitted by the licensee personally. (Ord. 01-22, 10-1-2001)
4-2-7: SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Administration: The mayor shall be charged with the administration of
this chapter.
   B.   Suspension Or Revocation Of License: The mayor may suspend or revoke
any license issued under the provisions of this chapter if it is determined
that the licensee has violated any of the provisions hereof.
   C.   Fine In Lieu Of Suspension Or Revocation: In lieu of suspension or
revocation of a license, the mayor may, instead, levy a fine on the licensee.
The fine imposed shall be not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00), nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues.
   D.   Hearing; Decisions:
      1.   Notice Of Hearing: No such license shall be suspended or revoked,
and no licensee shall be fined, except after a public hearing by the mayor
within a seven (7) day written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an
opportunity to appear and defend against the charges contained in such notice.
The seven (7) day notice provisions shall begin the day following delivery by
certified mail or personal service.
      2.   Mayor's Decision: The mayor shall, within seven (7) days after such
hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked
or suspended, or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason for such
determination in a written order and either the amount of the fine, the period
of suspension, or that the license has been revoked, and serve a copy of such
order within the seven (7) day time period upon the licensee.
   E.   Use Of Premises After License Revocation: When any license shall have
been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to any person for the
period of six (6) months thereafter for the conduct of the business of selling
tobacco products in the premises described in such revoked license. (Ord. 01-
22, 10-1-2001)
4-2-8: VIOLATIONS/PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction,
be fined no more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day on which
a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. (Ord. 01-22, 10-1-
2001; amd. Ord. 19-61, 12-16-2019)
CHAPTER 3
DUTCH ELM DISEASE
(Rep. by Ord. 08-11, 8-4-2008)
CHAPTER 4
NUISANCES
SECTION:
4-4-1: Junk Storage Prohibited
4-4-2: Weeds
4-4-3: Snow Removal Onto Public Property
4-4-4: Permitted Hours For Construction Activity
4-4-5: Permitted Hours For Outdoor Use Of Sound Amplification Equipment
4-4-6: Noise Standards
4-4-7: Penalty
4-4-1: JUNK STORAGE PROHIBITED:
   A.   Definitions:
   ABANDONED AUTOMOBILE: A motor vehicle, whether on public or private
property, with no current valid state registration, no current city of Batavia
vehicle sticker, a motor vehicle left unattended on a highway or public
property for a period in excess of twenty four (24) hours, a motor vehicle not
removed after its involvement in a collision, an unattended motor vehicle
located on a highway or public property which has sustained acts of vandalism,
a motor vehicle, wherever located, from which, for a period of at least seven
(7) days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or on which the
engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so
treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor
power. This shall not include registered historic vehicles or a motor vehicle
on the premises of a place of business engaged in ordinary service or repair
operations for a reasonable period of time, if such business premises is
properly zoned.
   JUNK, TRASH AND REFUSE: Includes any and all waste matter, whether reusable
or not, which is offensive to the public health, safety or to the aesthetics of
the neighborhood, which is not within a closed building, and is specifically
intended to include, but not be limited to, wrecked, disabled and/or abandoned
automobiles, trucks, tractors, machinery and/or motor vehicles of any kind, any
parts thereof, old refrigerators, stoves, washers, dryers and/or other
appliances. This definition shall not apply to a licensed junkyard which is in
full compliance with all ordinances of the city of Batavia. (Ord. 95-85, 10-16-
1995)
   B.   Storing Of Junk Declared A Nuisance: The storing of junk, trash and
refuse on private property within the city, where such storage is not
authorized under the terms of title 10, "Zoning", of this code, and in any
manner not permitted by such zoning title, is declared a nuisance. (1972 Code §
94.001)
   C.   Notice To Violators:
      1.   Any police officer or the inspector of the city, upon observing any
violation of this section, shall issue a notice directed to the owner of record
of the property on which said nuisance occurs, as shown in the records of the
recorder of deeds of Kane County, or to the occupant of said property, or to
both, which said notice shall describe the violation and shall establish a
reasonable time limit for the abatement thereof by such owner or occupant,
which time shall be not less than two (2) days nor more than ten (10) days
after service of such notice. (1972 Code § 94.010)
      2.   Any police officer or the inspector of the city shall serve the
notice herein provided for upon the owner or occupant of the property where
such nuisance exists, or upon both of them, and shall make his return upon a
copy of such notice, showing the time of service, the person upon whom it was
served, or the manner in which it was served. (1972 Code § 94.020)
   D.   Complaints By Citizens: Any citizen of the city who observes a
violation of this section may file his affidavit setting forth in detail the
violation, its location and the name of the owner and occupant of the property
on which such nuisance is alleged, and may file such affidavit with the
Inspector of the City, who shall make an investigation of such charge, and if
such nuisance exists, shall issue a notice to the owner or occupant of the
property as provided in subsection C of this Section. (1972 Code § 94.015)
   E.   Subsequent Investigation Of Compliance: Immediately upon the
termination of the time allowed in any such notice for the abatement of such
nuisance, the police officer or the inspector of the City who served such
notice, or any other police officer or inspector shall investigate to determine
whether or not such nuisance has been abated.
   F.   Procedure Upon Noncompliance: In the event the owner or occupant of the
property where such nuisance exists has failed within the prescribed time to
abate such nuisance, then the police officer or the inspector of the City who
served such notice, or the citizen of the City who filed an affidavit with the
inspector, who investigated whether such nuisance had been abated, shall file a
complaint charging violation of this Section with the Circuit Court for the
Sixteenth Judicial Circuit, or a magistrate thereof, charging violation of this
Section and demanding that the owner of the property or the occupant thereof,
or both, be punished as herein provided. (1972 Code § 94.030)
   G.   Prosecution By City: The City shall prosecute all complaints or
violations of this Section. (1972 Code § 94.035)
   H.   Penalty: Any property owner or any occupant of property who allows such
storage on the property owned or occupied by him shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more
than two hundred dollars ($200.00); and any person who shall neglect to abate
and remove such nuisance after notice thereof shall, for each twenty four (24)
hours thereafter during which such nuisance continues, be subject to a like
penalty as that originally incurred. (1972 Code § 94.999)
4-4-2: WEEDS:
   A.   Nuisance Declared: Any weed such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle,
cocklebur or other weeds of a like kind found growing in any lot or tract of
land in the City, are declared to be a nuisance, and it is unlawful to permit
any such weeds to grow or remain in any such place.
   B.   Height: It shall be unlawful to permit any weeds, grass or plants,
other than trees, bushes, flowers, or other ornamental plants to grow to a
height in excess of eight inches (8") anywhere in the City; any such plants or
weeds exceeding such height are declared to be a nuisance.
   C.   Barberry Bushes Prohibited: It is a nuisance and unlawful to plant or
permit the growth of the bush of the species of tall, common or european
barberry, further known as Barberis vulgaris or its horticultural varieties
within the City.
   D.   Abatement Notice - Service: It shall be the duty of the code
enforcement officer to serve or cause to be served a notice upon the owner or
occupant of any premises in which weeds or plants are permitted to grow in
violation of the provisions of this Section, such notice to contain mention of
the provisions of this Section and to demand the abatement of said nuisance
within five (5) days.
   E.   Abatement: If the person so served does not abate the nuisance within
said five (5) days, the code enforcement officer shall through the City Public
Works Department, proceed to abate such nuisance. The code enforcement officer
or the Public Works Department shall keep an account of the expense of the
abatement at the rate for such work established on a yearly basis by the Public
Works Department, a minimum charge of representing two (2) hours of such work,
and the expense shall be charged and paid by such owner or occupant.
   F.   Lien For Unpaid Charges: Charges for the abatement of said nuisance
under this Section shall be a lien upon the premises. Whenever a bill for such
charges remains unpaid for more than thirty (30) days, after it has been
rendered, the City Clerk may file with the Recorder of Deeds of Kane County a
statement of lien claims. The statement shall obtain a legal description of the
premises, the expenses and costs incurred and the date the nuisance was abated,
and the notice that the City claims a lien for such account. Notice of such
lien claim shall be mailed to the owner of the premises if his address is
known; provided, however that failure of the Clerk to record such lien claim or
to mail such notice, or the failure of the owner to receive such notice, shall
not affect the right to foreclose the lien for such charges as provided in the
following subsection.
   G.   Foreclosure Of Lien:
      1.   Property subject to a lien for unpaid expenses for the abatement of
a nuisance shall be sold for nonpayment of same and the proceeds of such sale
shall be applied to pay the charges after deducting costs, as in the case in
the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be maintained in the
name of the city.
      2.   The city attorney is authorized and directed to institute such
proceedings, in the name of the city and any court having jurisdiction over
such matter, against any property for which such bill has remained unpaid sixty
(60) days after it has been rendered. (Ord. 95-87, 10-16-1995)
4-4-3: SNOW REMOVAL ONTO PUBLIC PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful and it is hereby declared a public nuisance for any person
to remove snow from private property and deposit the same upon any public right
of way within the territorial limits of the city. (Ord. 80-22, 6-16-1980)
4-4-4: PERMITTED HOURS FOR CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITY:
It shall be unlawful and it is hereby declared a public nuisance within one
thousand feet (1,000') of any residentially zoned lot, for any heavy equipment
or power tools to be operated out of doors during the hours prior to seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. and after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. on weekdays and
Saturdays, and prior to eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and after nine o'clock (9:00)
P.M. on Sundays, unless otherwise authorized by the city council, or in cases
of emergency. Heavy equipment may be operated outside of said hours for the
sole purpose of loading and unloading for transport. (Ord. 13-27, 5-6-2013)
4-4-5: PERMITTED HOURS FOR OUTDOOR USE OF SOUND AMPLIFICATION EQUIPMENT:
It shall be unlawful and it is hereby declared a nuisance for any person to use
or allow the use, outdoors, of sound amplification equipment between the hours
of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. on Sunday through
Thursday, and from eleven thirty o'clock (11:30) P.M. until eight o'clock (8:
00) A.M. on Friday and Saturday. (Ord. 97-42, 6-16-1997)
4-4-6: NOISE STANDARDS:
   A.   Purpose:
      1.   It is hereby declared that excessive sound is a serious hazard to
the public health, welfare, safety, and the quality of life; a substantial body
of science and technology exists by which excessive sound may be substantially
abated; that the people have a right to and should be ensured an environment
free from excessive sound, and, therefore, it is the policy of the city of
Batavia to prevent excessive sound that may jeopardize the health, welfare, or
safety of the citizens or degrade the quality of life.
      2.   This section shall apply to the control of noise originating from
"industrial property" as defined in subsection B of this section.
   B.   Definitions: The following words and terms, when used in this section,
shall have the following meanings unless the context clearly indicates
otherwise:
   A-WEIGHTING: The electronic filtering in sound level meters that models
human hearing frequency sensitivity.
   AMBIENT SOUND LEVEL: The total sound level from all noise sources that make
up the character of the area of interest.
   BACKGROUND SOUND LEVEL: The sound level at a location that interferes with
the measurement of the noise source of interest and may include sources such as
ambient noise, electronic noise, and wind noise.
   BASS RUMBLE: Any sound that can be judged as a low frequency weighted or
heavy bass sound spectrum as judged by the city employee conducting the
measurements.
   COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Any premises, property, or facility located in any
"business zoning district" (title 10, chapter 11 of this code), and any
premises, property or facility located in any zoning district of the city
involving traffic in goods or furnishing of services for sale or profit,
including, but not limited to:
      1.   Banking and other financial institutions;
      2.   Dining establishments;
      3.   Establishments for providing retail or wholesale services;
      4.   Establishments for recreation and entertainment;
      5.   Office buildings;
      6.   Transportation and motor freight terminals; and
      7.   Warehouses.
   CONSTRUCTION: Any site preparation, assembly, erection, repair, alteration
or similar action, or demolition of buildings or structures.
   dBA: The overall, A-weighted sound pressure level of a sound.
   DAYTIME HOURS: Seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. local
time.
   DECIBEL (dB): The unit of measurement for sound pressure level at a
specified location.
   EFFECTIVE SOURCE NOISE LEVEL: The source noise level after an adjustment for
the adverse character of noise (including tonal, impulsive, bass or rumble
noise).
   EMERGENCY WORK: Any work or action necessary to deliver essential services
including, but not limited to, repairing water, gas, electric, telephone, sewer
facilities, or public transportation facilities, removing fallen trees on
public rights of way, or abating life threatening conditions.
   EQUIVALENT SOUND LEVEL (Or LEQ): The A-weighting sound level measured in
decibels with an integrating sound level meter and averaged on an energy basis
over a ten (10) second duration unless otherwise stated.
   IMPULSIVE SOUND: A sound having duration of less than one second with a
rapid onset and decay.
   INDUSTRIAL PROPERTY: Any premises, property, or facility involving the
fabrication, manufacture, production or transport of durable or nondurable
goods located in the city's "I-1 limited industrial district", the city's "I-
2 general industrial district" or any premises, property or facility involving
the fabrication, manufacture, production or transport of durable goods located
in any other zoning district of the city.
   INTEGRATING SOUND LEVEL METER: An instrument that measures sound pressure
levels conforming to type 1 or type 2 standards as specified in the latest
version of ANSI standard S1.4 and integrates the sound energy over a specified
time period. The resulting measure is referred to as the equivalent sound level
or LEQ.
   MOTOR VEHICLE: Any vehicle propelled or drawn on land by an engine or motor.
   MUFFLER: A sound dissipative device or system for attenuating the sound of
the escaping gases of an internal combustion engine.
   MUNICIPALITY: The city of Batavia.
   NIGHTTIME HOURS: Nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. local
time.
   NOISE: Any sound of such level, character and duration as to unreasonably
interfere with the enjoyment of life or property to be injurious to human
health or welfare, as set forth in subsection E of this section.
   PERSON: Any individual, corporation, company, association, society, firm,
partnership, joint stock company, the municipality or any political
subdivision, agency or instrumentality of the municipality.
   PROPERTY LINE: The imaginary line, including its vertical extension, that
separates one parcel of real property from another.
   RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY: Property located in any "residential zoning district"
of the city (title 10, chapter 10 of this code) and property located anywhere
in the city used for human habitation, including, but not limited to:
      1.   Private property used for human habitation;
      2.   Commercial living accommodations and commercial property used for
human habitation;
      3.   Recreational and entertainment property used for human habitation;
and
      4.   Community service or institutional property used for human occupancy
such as, but not limited to, schools, churches and public parks.
   SOURCE NOISE LEVEL: The equivalent sound level (or LEQ) of the noise
radiated from a source or group of sources and determined by subtracting (on an
energy basis) the background sound level - with the source(s) off - from the
total sound level - measured with the source(s) on.
   TONAL NOISE: Any sound that can be judged as a single pitch or set of single
pitches by the CCO.
   WEEKDAY: Any day, Monday through Friday, that is not a legal holiday.
   C.   Enforcement Powers, Duties And Qualifications:
      1.   The provisions of this section shall be enforced only by a city
employee designated by the city administrator who has noise assessment
certification ("designated city employee").
      2.   Noise assessment certification can be obtained by: a) completing an
instructional program from a noise control engineer certified by the Institute
of Noise Control Engineering (INCE); b) completing a training session from a
designated city employee certified by an INCE engineer; c) having completed an
instructional program in community noise from another qualified training source
and demonstrating skill and competence to a noise certified designated city
employee; or d) having education or experience or a combination thereof and
having demonstrated competence to a noise certified designated city employee.
      3.   Noise measurements shall be taken by a designated city employee
certified in noise assessment and shall be taken in accordance with the
procedures specified in subsection D of this section.
      4.   The city's building commissioner shall have the power to coordinate
the noise control activities of the city, review the actions of other municipal
departments, review public and private projects for compliance with this
section. The city's director of community development may act in the building
commissioner's absence.
   D.   Sound Measurement Procedures:
      1.   Insofar as practicable, sound measurements shall be made while the
source under investigation is operating at normal, routine conditions and, as
necessary, at other conditions, including, but not limited to, design, maximum,
and fluctuating rates.
      2.   All tests shall be conducted in accordance with the following
procedures:
         a.   The designated city employee shall, to the extent practicable,
identify all sources contributing to the noise at the point of measurement.
         b.   Measurements shall be taken at or within the property line of the
affected person.
         c.   The sound level meter must be calibrated using only a calibrator
recommended by the measuring instrument manufacturer before and after each
series of readings.
         d.   The calibrator must be checked at least once each year by the
manufacturer or other qualified laboratory. Written documentation of the
calibrator check must be kept with the equipment at all times.
         e.   If the sound level meter is dropped, stored for any length of
time in an environment outside the manufacturer's recommended limits, or
physically damaged, it shall be sent back to the manufacturer for inspection,
recalibration, and repair if necessary.
         f.   No outdoor measurements shall be taken:
            (1)   During periods when wind speeds (including gusts) exceed
fifteen (15) miles per hour;
            (2)   Without an acoustically acceptable windscreen properly
attached to the microphone;
            (3)   Under any condition that allows the measuring instrument to
become wet (e.g., rain, snow, or condensation); or
            (4)   When the ambient temperature is out of the range of the
tolerance of the measuring instrument.
      3.   The report for each measurement session shall include the latest
version of the "noise measurement worksheet" (attached to ordinance 05-33 as
exhibit A). This worksheet shall include, but not be limited to:
         a.   The date and times at which measurements are taken;
         b.   The results of the calibration check;
         c.   The weather conditions;
         d.   The identification of all monitoring equipment;
         e.   A description of the source(s) and its operating cycle; and
         f.   The total sound level (level with the sources in question
operating);
         g.   The background sound level (level without the sources in question
operating).
      4.   Prior to taking noise measurements the designated city employee
shall explore the vicinity of the source in question to identify other sound
sources that could affect measurements, to establish the approximate location
and character of the principal sound source, and to select suitable locations
from which to measure the sound radiated from the source in question.
      5.   When measuring sound, the sound level meter shall be set for A-
weighting, linear averaging, and the proper range (i.e., where the sound level
registers in the upper measurement range without exceeding its limits). The
sample duration shall be at least ten (10) seconds.
      6.   The measuring instrument shall be placed at a minimum height of
three feet (3') above the ground and from any reflective surface. The
microphone shall be held at arm's length and pointed at the source at the angle
recommended by the measuring instrument's manufacturer.
      7.   If temporary sound sources unrelated to the measurements are plainly
audible, such as aircraft flyovers, barking dogs, or moving motorcycles, the
measurements should be postponed until these extraneous sounds have negligible
effect on the sound levels of interest.
      8.   The observation session should last for a period of time sufficient
to ensure that the sound levels measured are typical of the source in question.
      9.   To determine the source sound level, the background levels shall be
subtracted from the measured total sound levels as given in the worksheet. If
the total level does not exceed the background level by two (2) dBs or more,
the source level cannot be derived and a violation of this section cannot be
substantiated.
   E.   Sound Level Limitations:
      1.   No person shall cause, allow, or permit the operation of any sound
source on "industrial property" as defined herein in such a manner as to create
an effective source noise level that exceeds the limits specified in table 1 of
this section when measured at or within the real property line of the receiving
property.
 
TABLE 1
MAXIMUM PERMISSIBLE EFFECTIVE SOURCE NOISE LEVELS
Industrial Property To: Daytime Hours Nighttime Hours
Industrial property     65            65
Commercial property     65            60
Residential property    60            50
 
         a.   The source noise level is determined by subtracting the total
measured sound level (i.e., the sound with the source on) from the background
sound level (i.e., the sound with the source off). If the noise source is
continuous and cannot be turned off to obtain a suitable background noise
reading, such a reading shall be obtained at a more distant location where the
noise is inaudible, yet the ambient sound level is similar in loudness and
character to what can be heard at the original receiver location.
         b.   The "effective" source noise level is determined by adjusting the
sound noise level for: 1) any adverse character (e.g., tonal, impulsive, bass),
and 2) for less than full time operation in any one hour period. Said
adjustments shall be made pursuant to the provisions of the "noise measurement
worksheet" (attached to ordinance 05-33 as exhibit A).
      2.   The following are exempt from the sound level limits within this
section:
         a.   Noise from emergency signaling devices or the generation of sound
in the performance of emergency work;
         b.   Noise from an exterior burglar alarm of any building provided
such burglar alarm shall terminate its operation within five (5) minutes of its
activation;
         c.   The generation of sound in situations within the jurisdiction of
the federal occupational safety and health administration.
         d.   Construction activity so long as same is in compliance with
section
4-4-4 of this chapter.
   F.   Specific Prohibited Acts:
      1.   No person shall cause, suffer, allow, or permit to be made verbally
or mechanically any noise disturbance, as defined in subsection E1 of this
section and which originates from any source as provided in subsection A2 of
this section.
      2.   No person shall cause, suffer, allow, or permit the following acts:
         a.   Operating or permitting the operation of any semitrailer or any
motor vehicle whose manufacturer's gross weight rating is in excess of ten
thousand (10,000) pounds, or any auxiliary equipment attached to such a
vehicle, for a period of longer than five (5) minutes in any hour while the
vehicle is stationary, for reasons other than traffic congestion or emergency
work, on a public right of way or public space within five hundred feet (500')
of "residential property", as defined in subsection B of this section. (Ord.
05-33, 8-1-2005)
4-4-7: PENALTY:
   A.   Violation of any provision of section
4-4-6 of this chapter shall be cause for a notice to appear to be issued by the
code compliance officer of the city.
   B.   Any person or entity that violates any provision of section
4-4-6 of this chapter shall be subject to a fine for each offense of not more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). If the violation is of a continuing
nature, each day during which it occurs shall constitute an additional,
separate and distinct offense, subject to the fine as set forth above. (Ord.
05-33, 8-1-2005)
CHAPTER 5
SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND CITY CURBSIDE COLLECTION PROGRAMS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Customers Served
4-5-2: Household Defined
4-5-3: Weekly Collections Required
4-5-4: Charges For Collection
4-5-5: Definition Of Solid Waste And Specifications For Containers
4-5-6: Requirements For Placement Of Solid Waste Containers
4-5-7: Deposits In Street Prohibited
4-5-8: Curbside Collection Programs
4-5-9: Penalty
Multi-Family Dwellings, Commercial, And Industrial Property Refuse
4-5-20: Definitions
4-5-21: Refuse, Recycling, Grease Container, And Compacting Equipment
Enclosures
4-5-22: Enclosure Standards And Design
4-5-23: Responsibilities Of Non-Residential Properties
4-5-24: Hours Of Operation
4-5-25: Removal Of Refuse And Debris
4-5-26: Penalty
4-5-27:    Nonconforming Properties
4-5-1: CUSTOMERS SERVED:
   The contractor shall collect all solid waste from all residences within the
city according to the prescribed schedule as established by the city. The
contractor shall perform such service once weekly for each residence between
the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. of the same
day and no collections shall be made on Sunday.
(Ord. 06-07, 4-3-2006; amd. Ord. 2024-032, 4-15-2024)
4-5-2: HOUSEHOLD DEFINED:
   The term "household" as used in this chapter means each dwelling, or portion
thereof, including homes, multiple occupancy buildings up to six (6) units, but
shall not include commercial or industrial buildings. The number of households
shall be determined and evidenced by the number of separate electric light
meters.
(Ord. 03-11, 3-17-2003; amd. Ord. 2024-032, 4-15-2024)
4-5-3: WEEKLY COLLECTIONS REQUIRED:
   The current accumulation of solid waste shall be collected once each week
from each dwelling and household located in the city, said collection to be
made by a person with whom the city has contracted for such collection.
(Ord. 03-11, 3-17-2003; amd. Ord. 2024-032, 4-15-2024)
4-5-4: CHARGES FOR COLLECTION:
   A.   All charges for solid waste collection shall be set in the contract
with whom the city of Batavia has contracted for such collection.
(Ord. 03-11, 3-17-2003; amd. Ord. 2024-032, 4-15-2024)
4-5-5: DEFINITION OF SOLID WASTE AND SPECIFICATIONS FOR CONTAINERS:
   A.   Placement: All solid waste for collection and disposal must be placed
in covered cans, approved bags or containers, at the street curb, of any
household premises, readily accessible.
   B.   Definition: The term "solid waste" shall include, but not be limited
to, all household and kitchen wastes, such as discarded food or food residues
and paper necessarily used for wrapping same, tin cans, bottles, books, paper,
newspapers, boxes, cartons and glass. "Yard waste" as defined in subsection F
of this section shall not be mixed in with solid waste. All solid waste shall
be in a suitable container of tightly covered metal or other noncorrodible
material, watertight, not to exceed thirty two (32) gallon capacity each and a
total weight when filled up to fifty (50) pounds each.
   C.   Durability: The solid waste containers shall be durable in all types of
weather.
   D.   Condemned Containers: Any containers that cannot any longer be
classified as "durable" may be condemned by the contractor and disposed of by
the contractor without any liability for such disposal.
   E.   Remodeling Waste: Home remodeling and repair construction materials
will be accepted for pick up provided such items are placed in suitable
containers as previously stated or necessary bundles tied together not
exceeding four feet (4') in length and not weighing over fifty (50) pounds per
container or bundle.
   F.   Yard Waste Collection: "Yard waste", defined as sod, earth, grass, lawn
clippings and leaves, will be collected separately from solid waste and a total
weight when filled up to fifty (50) pounds each. Such materials will only be
collected if they are placed in a suitable container marked "yard waste" and
displaying the city yard waste sticker or special paper collection bag
identified by the city logo made available to the general public by the city
contract through local retail outlets.
(Ord. 03-11, 3-17-2003; amd. Ord. 2024-032, 4-15-2024)
4-5-6: REQUIREMENTS FOR PLACEMENT OF SOLID WASTE CONTAINERS:
   All solid waste to be collected shall be placed, by each owner or tenant of
a household, in a covered container upon the tree bank or alley adjacent to the
dwelling, as the requirement may be, no earlier than the day preceding the day
on which collection is scheduled and not later than six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on
the day of collection. The containers shall be so placed in a manner that is
readily accessible for the collection on the day or days which are scheduled
for the area in which said dwelling or household is located. Empty containers
shall be removed as soon as possible, but in no event later than eight o'clock
(8:00) P.M. on the day of collection.
(Ord. 03-11, 3-17-2003; amd. Ord. 2024-032, 4-15-2024)
4-5-7: DEPOSITS IN STREET PROHIBITED:
   It shall be unlawful to deposit any solid waste of any kind in or on any
public street, alley or sidewalk or other public way; and it shall be unlawful
to place or deposit any solid waste in such a place or container that the same
can be blown about by ordinary winds.
(Ord. 03-11, 3-17-2003; amd. Ord. 2024-032, 4-15-2024)
4-5-8: CURBSIDE COLLECTION PROGRAMS:
   A.   Brush Collection Program: Once a month during the months of April
through October brush will be picked up providing the following standards are
met: All brush and tree branches shall be placed in the same direction in the
parkway in lengths not to exceed ten feet (10') and said brush or branches
shall not extend into the street or over the sidewalk. Individual branches or
limbs may not exceed ten inches (10") in diameter. Brush and limbs must be
stacked in large piles and not spread out. Individual branches, logs and limbs
exceeding ten inches (10") in diameter, stumps, yard waste and foreign material
will not be collected. The city will establish a pick up schedule made known to
the public through local media and the city newsletter. All brush and limbs to
be collected shall be placed by each owner or tenant of a household in the
parkway in front of the dwelling, no earlier than the Friday, Saturday, or
Sunday preceding the first day of the scheduled collection and not later than
six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the first day of the scheduled collection. This
program is specifically limited to residential properties only.
   B.   Fall Leaf Collection: During October and November the city will provide
leaf collection at curbside under the following guidelines. This program is
specifically for residential use only.
      1.   The city will establish a pick up schedule made known to the public
through local media and the city newsletter.
      2.   The city will, during the designated pick up week, collect those
leaves lying on the parkway, within two feet (2') of the curbs, or within two
feet (2') of the street pavement if there are no curbs. Leaves must not be
placed in the streets or on curbs.
   C.   Leaf And Brush Collection: Effective with utility bills mailed after
January 1, 2017, all residential units (other than apartments, condominiums or
townhouse developments in excess of six (6) units) shall be charged a five
dollar ($5.00) per month fee for the leaf and brush pick up services, said fee
to appear as a separate line item on the utility bill for the residential
units.
      1.   Leaves shall be picked up according to the program specified by the
city.
      2.   Brush shall be picked up according to the program specified by the
city.
      3.   Leaves, brush and landscaping waste may be disposed of under the
terms of the city's contract with its solid waste collection provider.
(Ord. 06-07, 4-3-2006; amd. Ord. 16-79, 12-19-2016; Ord. 2024-032, 4-15-2024)
4-5-9: PENALTY:
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues.
(Ord. 03-11, 3-17-2003; amd. Ord. 2024-032, 4-15-2024)
