8-1B-1: DEFINITIONS:
   AMPACITY: The maximum current a conductor can carry continuously without
adversely affecting its electrical or mechanical properties.
   AMPERE (A): A unit of electrical current that is equivalent to a steady
current produced by one volt applied across a resistance of one ohm.
   BONDING CONDUCTOR: A suitably sized copper conductor used for connecting an
earth ground electrode to a system ground electrode.
   CSS: Customer service station.
   CABLE TERMINATION: A device installed at the connection point of an
underground cable to limit voltage stresses on the cable's insulation.
Additionally, it provides a method for the mechanical connection of a cable to
an equipment bushing or terminal.
   CAPACITOR: A device used to store a fixed amount of electrical charge. In an
alternating current system it is used to supply reactive power. Usually
installed in parallel with inductive loads to increase the power factor of an
installation.
   CONDUIT OR RIGID CONDUIT: A watertight pipe (steel, aluminum, or
intermediate metallic tubing) suitable for containing electrical conductors.
   CURRENT TRANSFORMER: A device used to transform the current which is
actually drawn by an installation into a current of lesser magnitude (0-5 amps)
by a fixed ratio.
   DEMAND (kW): The highest kilowatt consumption established by an installation
during the billing period.
   DEMAND REGISTER: A device within the kilowatt hour meter which is used to
record the highest kilowatt usage during the billing period.
   ESS: Electric service station.
   EASEMENT: A grant by a property owner for the use of a strip of land by the
general public, a corporation or a certain person or persons, for a specific
purpose or purposes.
   FENCE: A barrier intended to prevent unauthorized entry into areas which may
contain energized equipment or conductors.
   FOUNDATION: A suitably sized concrete base capable of supporting equipment
without experiencing deformation or damage. Foundations are so constructed as
to remain level.
   FUSE: A device consisting of a fusible metal strip or wire which melts at a
pre-set magnitude of current. Used to interrupt circuits under overload or
fault conditions. The fuse must be of an adequate interrupting rating for its
particular location in the system.
   FUSED DISCONNECTS: A device of suitable interrupting rating which can be
operated manually to disconnect all conductors except the grounded neutral
conductor from the source of supply and provided with properly sized
overcurrent protection.
   GROUND: An object used to make an electrical connection to the earth in
order to provide a near resistance-free return path for the flow of electrical
current.
   INSTRUMENT TRANSFORMERS: Transformer used to transform utilization voltage
into low voltage (0-120 volts) and utilization current into low magnitude
current (0-5 amps). The low voltages and low magnitude currents derived are
characteristically used to operate metering equipment or relays.
   INSULATION: Material which cannot readily conduct electrical current.
   INTERFERENCE: Voltage fluctuations of such a magnitude and frequency as to
adversely affect or annoy other customers of the Utility.
   INTERRUPTING RATING: The maximum electrical current that an electrical
device can safely interrupt.
   KILOVAR (kVAR): Unit which represents one thousand (1,000) VARS where VAR
represents volt-amperes-reactive and is used to measure reactive power.
Inductors and capacitors are devices responsible for the presence of reactive
power.
   KILOVOLT (kV): Unit which represents one thousand (1,000) volts.
   KILO-VOLT-AMPERE (kVA): Unit which represents one thousand (1,000) VA where
a VA represents the vector sum of the real and reactive components of power.
Also known as apparent power.
   KILOWATT (kW): Unit which represents one thousand (1,000) watts where a watt
is used to measure real power. A watt is equal the power expended in a resistor
of one ohm which experiences a current flow of one ampere.
   KILOWATT-HOUR: The power consumed by a continuous one thousand (1,000) watt
load in a period of one hour. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-2: OBTAINING INFORMATION:
   A.   The term "Utility" shall be used herein to refer to the City of Batavia
Municipal Electric Utility.
   B.   Information desired from the Utility relative to subject matters
covered by these policies may be obtained by personally visiting, telephoning
or corresponding with the office of the Superintendent of Electric or the
Batavia Municipal Center. A copy of this Article will be available for public
inspection at the office of the Superintendent of Electric or the Batavia
Municipal Building during normal business hours, eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to
five o'clock (5:00) P.M., weekdays. A bound copy of this Article may also be
purchased at the Batavia Municipal Building for the sum of ten dollars ($10.00)
per copy.
   C.   Throughout this Article the standards for electrical installations set
forth by the National Electric Code are required, except when in conflict with
the requirements of this Article. This refers to the latest issue of the
National Electric Code as adopted by the National Fire Protection Association
and approved by the American National Standards Institute 1 . (Ord. 82-39)
 
Notes
1 1. See also Title 9, Chapter 5 of this Code.
8-1B-3: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE; GENERAL INFORMATION:
   A.   Application for an original service or service connection or an
upgraded service or service connection by the Utility shall be submitted by
customer or his agent in writing at the office of the Building Inspector at the
earliest date possible prior to the expected date of the required improvement.
Examples of the applications to be filled out by an owner, customer or
developer requesting an original service or service connection or an upgraded
service or service connection for a residence, or for an industrial or
commercial development shall be on file in the office of the Building
Inspector. Before these applications can be accepted or acted upon, it will be
the responsibility of the party requesting the improvement to ensure that the
appropriate form is filled out accurately and in its entirety.
   B.   The application for electric service form shall be required to be
submitted for any work to be performed within the service territory of the
Utility. Residential properties that have been annexed to the City after 1996,
and whose electrical service was provided by ComEd at the time of annexation,
shall be required to disconnect from ComEd and connect to City of Batavia
Municipal Electric as a condition of the City's approval of any application for
new electric service, or changes in existing electric service, so long as City
Municipal Electric facilities are located within two hundred feet (200') of the
applicant' s closest property boundary. Any work done by a customer or his
agent without the filing of this document shall be considered in violation of
this Article.
   C.   Any person violating any provisions of this Article shall be fined not
less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred dollars
($200.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
   D.   It shall be the responsibility of the customer to supply the Utility
with all the information necessary for the Utility to inform the customer if
the type of service requested is available at a particular location within our
service territory.
   E.   Certain types of electrical service configurations are not available in
every locality within our service territory. The type of service which can be
provided at any particular location will be determined by one or more of the
following conditions:
Configuration of service lines available at that location.
Available system capacity at that location.
Voltage of service lines at that location.
Type of load to be served.
   F.   The standard types of service and secondary utilization voltages for
loads which are to be supplied within our service territory are as follows:
Single-phase, three-wire, 120/240 volt service
Three-phase, four-wire Wye, 120/208 volt service
Three-phase, four-wire Delta, 240 volt service
Three-phase, four-wire Wye, 277/480 volt service
Three-phase, three-wire Delta, 480 volt service
   G.   Customers and potential customers whose installations may require
service voltages other than those normally available, as described in
subsection F, are requested to consult the Superintendent of Electric in order
to determine the conditions under which such a type of service can be provided
by the Utility.
   H.   The voltage of lines supplying a customer's load shall be determined by
the Utility on the basis of the size and characteristics of the customer's load
and its relation to the facilities located in or projected for the area in
which the customer is to be served or is presently being served.
   I.   Should it become necessary, strictly in the interest of the Utility, to
change the voltage or characteristics of lines entering the property of an
existing customer, the Utility shall bear the costs associated with modifying
or replacing the existing facilities in order to provide the same level of
electric service as was available prior to the date of the required change.
   J.   Should it become necessary to change the voltage or the characteristics
of the lines entering the property of an existing customer in order to prevent
undue or unacceptable interference with the service to other customers, by
reason of a change in the characteristics of a customer's load, or due to the
request of a customer or his agent, the following guidelines shall be used to
determine the apportionment between the Utility and the customer of the costs
of the facilities necessary to enable the customer to receive service at the
new voltage. These costs include, but are not limited to, the cost of providing
additional transformation facilities, and the costs associated with providing
an upgraded service connection to the utility's distribution system.
      1.   The utility shall bear the costs as required to provide for the
customer's existing load. The term “existing load,” as used, shall represent
the highest fifteen (15) minute or thirty (30) minute demand (whichever is
applicable) recorded by the utility due to the customer' s facilities prior to
the date of the required changes.
      2.   The customer shall bear the costs as required to provide for
additional load beyond the existing load. The term “existing load” is defined
in subsection J1 of this section.
      3.   It shall be the responsibility of the customer to supply the utility
with the information necessary for the utility to supply the customer with an
accurate estimate of all the costs which will be incurred in providing a
particular installation.
   K.   Upon receipt of an application such as described in subsection A of
this section and in response to a written request by a customer, the utility
will furnish an estimate of the charges which will be incurred by the customer
due to the improvement requested. This figure supplied to the customer shall be
based on the facts and information which are made available by the customer at
the time the estimate is arrived at. The estimate shall be based upon the most
economical service plan consistent with good engineering and operating practice
determined by the utility and in accordance with all applicable codes and
regulations. In producing estimates of this nature, the utility will use the
form on file in the office of the building inspector. (Ord. 82-39; amd. Ord.
22-30, 6-6-2022)
8-1B-4: EXTENSIONS:
If an extension of the utility' s system becomes necessary in order to service
a new development, redevelopment or upgrade an existing electric service, the
utility shall design, construct and furnish the necessary electrical
distribution facilities to provide electrical service. The developer or
customers shall pay the city the estimated cost of such extension as a
condition of final plat recordation, or building permit issuance. Upon
completion of the utility extension, as-built costs shall be calculated by the
city and provided to the developer or customers and any adjustments, if
necessary, shall be paid by the developer or customers or reimbursed by the
city. If prior to construction, and based on the following considerations, the
extension is deemed to be in the best interest of the utility and city, then
the utility and city may elect to enter into a formal written reimbursement
agreement with the developer or customers to codify cost sharing for the
extension work. Any potential cost sharing shall be administered as a
reimbursement after construction has been completed. Considerations in the
formation of a written agreement which changes the responsibility for extension
costs may include, but are not limited to:
   A.   The probability that additional developments or customers will utilize
such extension, based upon the city's corporate limits and the amount of
undeveloped property, if any, near the extension;
   B.   The extent to which the extension, at the utility's request, is larger
than reasonably necessary to serve the development;
   C.   The extent to which other modifications to the utility system are
required elsewhere;
   D.   Economic development considerations which could result in arrangements
for lessened or structured payments over time of such costs, including, but not
limited to:
      1.   The extent to which a new customer's power requirements, or a
current customer's increase in power requirements, allows the utility to
effectuate calculable savings by purchasing power in a different manner;
      2.   The size and duration of the increase in power requirements;
      3.   The extent to which a new customer provides financial assurance for
either the purchase of an amount of power and/or system improvements necessary
for the customer; and
      4.   The extent to which any modifications to the system for a new
customer can be used by others in the event the new customer leaves, or
substantially decreases its power requirements. (Ord. 89-29, 7-17-1989; amd.
Ord. 82-39; Ord. 10-05, 3-1-2010; Ord. 22-41, 9-6-2022)
8-1B-5: TEMPORARY SERVICE; DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
A customer desiring temporary service of any kind shall be required to fill out
the appropriate application for electric service form. As soon as possible
after the proper application is received by the utility, an estimate of the
costs of furnishing, installing and removing the required facilities to provide
for the temporary service shall be mailed to the address, as supplied on the
application form, of the party requesting the service. Additionally, a charge
of fifty dollars ($50.00) will be included in the estimate as a deposit to
insure the return of the meter supplied. This deposit shall be returned to the
customer upon return of the meter. If after reviewing the estimate supplied by
the Utility, the customer wishes to proceed with the installation of a
temporary service, the estimated cost figure provided shall be paid in advance
by check made out to the City of Batavia before any work shall be performed by
the Utility. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-6: CROSSING ADJACENT PROPERTY:
If, in order to supply service to a customer, it becomes necessary to cross
adjacent property, then the customer shall be responsible for securing and
maintaining the consent of the owner of the adjacent property for an easement
or right of way dedicated to the City which will accommodate the necessary
facilities. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-7: INSPECTION:
The Utility shall have the right to inspect the installation of customer-owned
electric service entrance equipment, including, but not limited to, grounding
facilities, metering sockets and customer-owned service connections up to the
service panel, as a prerequisite for supplying electric service. However, the
Utility will not assume any responsibility for the adequacy, safety or
satisfactory performance of the equipment and facilities installed and
maintained by the customer. If upon inspection of customer-owned facilities by
representatives of the Utility, the facilities are found to be in an inadequate
or unsafe condition, the Utility shall require the facilities brought up to
present standards as soon as practicable thereafter as a requirement for
continued electric service. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-8: EXCESS FACILITIES:
   A.   The following shall hereupon be referred to as standard service
installations:
      1.   For single-family and duplex residential customers, a standard
service shall consist of a service of 100 amps of capacity per dwelling unit
and supplied at a standard utilization voltage of 120/240 volt, single-phase,
three-wire.
      2.   For commercial and industrial customers, a standard service shall
consist of a service of not more than thirty (30) kVA of maximum demand as
recorded in a fifteen (15) or thirty (30) minute (whichever is applicable)
sampling period and supplied at one of the standard utilization voltages
referred to in subsection
8-1B-3F of this Article.
   B.   Should an existing customer wish to upgrade their electric service
beyond the standard service installation which is supplied by the Utility, the
following guidelines shall be used to determine the apportionment between the
Utility and the customer of the costs of the facilities necessary to supply the
increased capacity:
      1.   The Utility will bear the costs as required to provide for the
customer's existing load.
         a.   For residential customers, this Section stipulates that the
customer will receive credit for any salvage value of the existing facilities
removed. This will consist only of the aerial service drop wires removed from
the existing installation. For the purposes of this Section, underground
secondary wires will not be considered salvageable.
         b.   For commercial or industrial customers, this Section stipulates
that the customer will receive credit for the salvage value of the existing
facilities removed which will consist of aerial service lines, and salvageable
transformer capacity. For the purposes of this Section, underground secondary
wires not in conduit will not be considered salvageable. It shall be the
responsibility of the Utility to supply the first thirty (30) kVA of capacity
as defined in subsection A2 of this Section.
      2.   The customer shall bear the costs as required to provide for
additional load beyond the standard service provided by the Utility.
      3.   It shall be the responsibility of the customer to supply the Utility
with all the information necessary for the Utility to supply the customer with
an ac- curate estimate of all the costs which will be incurred in providing a
particular installation.
   C.   Before proceeding with plans to upgrade an existing service, the
customer is required to refer to subsection
8-1B-3A of this Article for the procedures regulating such a request and to
subsection
8-1B-3K of this Article with respect to obtaining cost estimates from the
Utility related to the work proposed. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-9: CUSTOMER-OWNED FACILITIES:
Should the customer choose to furnish, install, own or maintain facilities used
in conjunction with, or in lieu of, those provided by the Utility for the
connection and supply of electric service, such facilities shall be subject to
Utility approval, as to necessity, type and method of installation. (Ord. 82-
39)
8-1B-10: RESALE:
The Utility prohibits the furnishing of electricity by a customer to a third
person or persons. It is, therefore, necessary that each individual occupancy
in a new multiple-occupancy premises be provided with a separate meter. When a
customer elects to upgrade the existing electrical facilities in an existing
building, the installation of the upgraded facilities shall have to conform to
the requirement established by this Section as well as this Article. (Ord. 82-
39)
8-1B-11: TRANSFORMER INSTALLATION:
8-1B-11-1: REQUIRED FACILITIES:
Where line voltage (2,400 volts or higher) is reduced on the customer's
property to the service voltage required by the customer, the facilities
necessary to accommodate the transformer or transformers shall be designated as
follows:
   A.   An electric service station (ESS) if furnished, installed, owned,
operated and maintained by the Utility.
   B.   A customer service station (CSS) if furnished, installed, owned,
operated and maintained by the customer. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-11-2: ELECTRIC SERVICE STATION:
   A.   An electric service station shall include transformers, metering
equipment, foundations, fencing, land rights, primary cables (from a distance
of 10 feet beyond the lot line of the customer's property to the site of the
ESS), cable terminations, switches, fusing or protection, conduit and required
appurtenances.
   B.   Upon inspection of the application submitted by a prospective customer,
following the procedure outlined in subsection 8-1B-3A of this Article, the
Utility will determine the most practical and economical method by which to
provide service to the prospective customer. Where practical, such customers
shall be served from an electric service station.
      1.   If it is determined from the information provided in the required
application form filled out by the customer that a customer's projected load
shall be less than or equal to what is defined as a standard service
installation in subsection
8-1B-8A2 of this Article, the Utility shall bear the costs of providing such
facilities.
         a.   Should it be necessary to obtain space on the customer's property
in order to locate such installation, the customer shall provide this space at
no cost to the Utility.
         b.   The location of such facilities shall be determined by the
Utility as dictated by the following conditions:
            (1)   Location of existing service lines with respect to customer's
property. (Ord. 82-39)
            (2)   Accessibility of location to Utility personnel. The Utility
must have nonobstructed access to such facilities in order to perform
inspection, maintenance and replacement of said facilities at the discretion of
the Utility. (Ord. 82-39; amd. Ord. 89-28, 7-3-1989)
         c.   All electric facilities located beyond the secondary bushings of
the transformer in an ESS shall be furnished, installed, owned and maintained
by the customer. These facilities shall be subject to the provisions of the
National Electric Code as published by the National Fire Protection
Association.
            (1)   Connection to transformer secondary bushings shall be made by
the customer and shall be made exclusively by the use of compression-type
connectors. (Ord. 82-39)
            (2)   The installation and maintenance of any fencing required by
utilities shall be the responsibility of the customer.
      2.   If it is determined from the information provided in the application
form that a customer's projected load will be greater than what is defined as a
standard installation in subsection
8-1B-8A2 of this Article, a customer shall be required to pay a service
connection fee equal to the installed costs of the electric service station
required to serve the projected load. (Ord. 89-28, 7-3-1989)
         a.   Should it be necessary to obtain space on the customer's property
in order to locate such installation, the customer shall provide this space at
no cost to the Utility.
         b.   The location of such facilities shall be determined by the
Utility as dictated by the following conditions:
            (1)   Location of existing service lines with respect to customer's
property.
            (2)   Accessibility of location to Utility personnel. The Utility
must have nonobstructed access to such facilities in order to perform
inspection, maintenance and replacement of said facilities at the discretion of
the Utility.
         c.   All electric facilities located beyond the secondary bushings of
the transformer in an ESS shall be furnished, installed, owned and maintained
by the customer. These facilities shall be subject to the provisions of the
National Electric Code as published by the National Fire Protection
Association.
            (1)   Connection to transformer secondary bushings shall be made by
the customer and shall be made exclusively by the use of compression-type
connector. (Ord. 82-39)
            (2)   The installation and maintenance of any fencing required by
utilities will be the responsibility of the customer. (Ord. 89-28, 7-3-1989)
         d.   If the customer's utilization requires electricity to be
distributed on the premises at line voltage (2,400 volts or higher), the
facilities necessary to accommodate the primary metering equipment may of
themselves constitute the electric service station (ESS). Any facilities beyond
such primary metering will be considered to be part of a customer service
station (CSS).
   C.   As a result of the long lead times associated with securing customer
transformation facilities necessary in order to provide service beyond what is
defined as a standard service in subsection
8-1B-8A2 of this Article, the following procedure has been established in order
to facilitate the purchase of these transformers.
      1.   A completed application form for residential and for commercial/
industrial customers, shall be submitted by the customer to the Utility at the
earliest date prior to the award of a building permit by the City. (Ord. 82-39)
      2.   The Electric Superintendent shall review the application, consult
with the applicant if necessary, and specify the amount of the connection fee
as determined from the Electric Department fee schedule. The Electric
Superintendent shall enter this information on the service connection
authorization form and submit copies of this document to the office of the
Building Inspector.
      3.   The Electric Superintendent shall then mail the service connection
authorization form along with a letter of electric service requirements to the
customer.
      4.   Upon receiving the signed service connection authorization form from
the customer, the Electric Superintendent shall submit the proper material
requisition along with transformer specifications to the Purchasing Agent.
Additionally, the signed service connection authorization form shall be sent to
the Billing Department for processing.
      5.   The customer shall be required to pay the service connection fee
prior to the installation of the requested service, and within a period of
thirty (30) days from billing. (Ord. 89-28, 7-3-1989)
8-1B-11-3: CUSTOMER SERVICE STATION:
   A.   A customer service station may include transformers, metering
equipment, foundations, fencing, land rights, primary cables (from the take-off
point on the Utility's system), cable terminations, switches, fusing or
protection, conduit and required appurtenance.
   B.   A customer service station shall be furnished, owned, installed,
operated and maintained by the customer.
   C.   As a result of a customer request and after a determination of
compliance with subsection
8-1B-3A of this Article, the approval of such a Utility connection to a
customer service station shall be subject to the following conditions:
      1.   The Utility will primary meter the installation regardless of size.
The cost of the necessary metering facilities shall be borne by the customer.
      2.   The Utility shall assume responsibility only for the service wires
to the point of take-off from the Utility's facilities.
      3.   The facilities which shall comprise the CSS shall be subject to
approval of the Utility.
      4.   Appropriate measures shall be taken by the customer in the design of
the CSS in order to provide for means to disconnect the customer's equipment
from the incoming service lines should a problem develop with the customer's
equipment which may affect service to other customers. These measures shall be
subject to the recommendations and approval of the Utility.
      5.   The Utility assumes no responsibility for the adequacy, safety or
satisfactory performance of the equipment and facilities owned and installed by
the customer. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-12: OVERHEAD AND UNDERGROUND SERVICE CONNECTIONS:
   A.   An overhead or underground secondary service connection is that portion
of the supply conductors, with appropriate connectors, between the Utility's
secondary distribution system and the customer's service entrance equipment.
   B.   Should a customer require a service connection, whether an initial
connection or an upgraded connection, he shall be required to fill out the
necessary forms as required in subsection
8-1B-3A of this Article.
      1.   For an original service connection, a fee shall be required in
advance at the time the application for electric service is submitted in order
for the Utility to provide the requested service connection. This sum may be
included along with the balance of the fees submitted prior to the award of a
building permit by the City's Building Inspector. This sum shall only cover the
costs associated with the installation of a standard overhead or underground
service connection as defined below. Any installation which exceeds the
standard service connection in length shall incur an additional per foot charge
as indicated in the fee schedule on file in the office of the Building
Inspector.
         a.   A standard overhead service connection shall not exceed one
hundred twenty five feet (125') in length from the Utility take-off point to
the location of the customer's service attachment.
         b.   A standard underground service connection shall not exceed one
hundred feet (100') in length from the Utility take-off point to the location
of the customer's meter enclosure.
      2.   The following procedure must be followed before a customer can
receive an upgraded service drop:
         a.   Upon receipt of an application for electric service form such as
described in subsection
8-1B-3A, the Utility shall furnish to the customer an estimate of the charges
which will be incurred by the customer in order to provide the service
improvements requested. This figure supplied to the customer shall be based on
the information which is available at the time the estimate is provided and
shall be the most economical service plan consistent with good engineering and
operating practice as determined by the Utility and in accordance with all
applicable codes and regulations. In producing estimates of this nature, the
Utility will use the appropriate form. This estimated cost should be considered
as a sum-not-to-exceed figure by the customer. A copy of this form shall be
mailed to the customer within five (5) business days of the receipt of the
application.
         b.   Upon receipt of the estimate, the customer, in order to proceed
with the improvement, must pay a fee equal to the estimate furnished by the
Utility.
         c.   Upon receipt of payment from the customer, the Billing Department
shall fill out a service request form. After receipt of a service request form,
the Utility shall schedule the work within five (5) business days thereafter.
The improvement shall be completed as soon as possible after that date; weather
permitting.
         d.   Once the work is completed, a work order form shall be filled out
covering the labor, equipment and material charges associated with the actual
installation of the improvement. A copy of this form shall be submitted to the
Billing Department for processing. If the figure from the work order is less
than that advanced by the customer, a credit in the sum of the difference shall
be mailed to the customer. No further action shall be taken if the estimate is
at or below the sum of the actual figure.
   C.   The allowable total length of an overhead service drop beyond what is
considered standard will be determined by the Utility on the basis of the
conductor size required and on the characteristics of the pole from which the
service conductors originate.
   D.   If an overhead service connection is longer than the allowable length
of a service drop and requires intermediate supports, the service drop shall be
considered the portion between the Utility's distribution facilities and the
first point of attachment on the customer's property. The remainder of the
service connection, including the first support on private property, shall be
furnished, installed, owned and maintained by the Utility at the customer's
expense.
   E.   Under no circumstances shall an underground service connection be
provided which is to be covered by a deck, porch, walk or any other building
addition without the installation, by the customer, of a suitable duct through
which the Utility may pull its service conductors. Approval must be obtained
from the Utility regarding the size and type of duct to be provided.
   F.   Should a customer desire to place a deck, porch, walk or any other
building addition above an existing underground service connection, the
customer shall choose to follow one of the following two (2) options:
      1.   Customer may apply for an upgraded service connection to be
installed at the present location but following the conditions as set forth in
subsection E of this Section.
      2.   Customer may apply for an upgraded service connection to be
installed in a different location not affected by the proposed building
addition.
   G.   A building or other structure shall be served by a single service
connection and provisions shall be made by the customer in order to provide for
a single point of metering. Article 230 of the National Electric Code as
published by the National Fire Protection Association should be consulted for
further requirements related to this subsection.
   H.   A multiple-occupancy building shall be treated as a single premises
with respect to the number of service connections which shall be provided by
the Utility. Article 230 of the National Electric Code as published by the
National Fire Protection Association should be consulted for further
requirements related to this subsection.
   I.   For multiple-occupancy residences where two (2) or more meter sockets
are required, the customer will service all the meter sockets from a common
overhead or underground service cable. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-13: OVERHEAD SERVICE ATTACHMENT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Definition: A service attachment is a device used to secure an overhead
service connection to a building or other structural support on the customer's
premises. A service attachment may consist of insulating knobs, eye-bolts or
other approved devices depending on the requirements.
   B.   The service attachment shall, in all cases, be furnished and installed
by the customer and shall meet the requirements and specification of the
Utility.
   C.   The service attachment shall be located at a point designated by the
Utility and shall be sufficiently high above ground to maintain the minimum
clearances as specified by paragraph (232) of General Order 160 of the Illinois
Commerce Commission and ANSI C2-National Electrical Safety Code, latest
edition.
   D.   Under no circumstances shall a service attachment be located on a
parapet or a chimney.
   E.   In case a building is too low to provide for the minimum clearance
required, a riser or a roof bracket shall be installed in accordance with the
Utility's specifications.
   F.   The service head and attachment shall be so that the following
conditions are met:
      1.   All wiring which is outside of the riser shall adequately clear
downspouts, gutters and other building appurtenances.
      2.   All wiring which is external to the riser shall be out of reach of
windows, porches or any other part of a building ordinarily accessible to the
occupants or the public.
   G.   The Utility shall, in all cases, make the final connection of the
customer's wiring facilities to the Utility's overhead service drop. The
customer or his agent shall be prohibited from disconnecting, connecting or
making any changes to the Utility's service conductors.
   H.   The customer or his agent shall be prohibited from disconnecting,
connecting or making any changes to conductors on the line side of meter
sockets, without first obtaining approval from the Utility. By granting this
approval, the Utility assumes no responsibility for any action of the customer
or his agent which results in injury, death or property damage.
   I.   If, because of public improvements such as street widening, grading,
excavating or other reasons beyond the Utility's control, the Utility must move
facilities with which it serves the customer, the Utility, as a condition of
continued service, may require that a new service connection be established
under the same terms as an original service connection from the standpoint of
Utility and customer expense and installation. Implementation of this
subsection shall be subject to City Council approval.
   J.   If, because of planned Utility revitalization, it becomes necessary to
change the location or style of the service entrance facilities by the
customer, the Utility will assume the responsibility for furnishing and
installing service entrance facilities which provide the same level and
capacity of service which was available prior to the improvement. As a
requirement for continued service, the customer must provide access and
permission to the Utility or its agents to move or replace the existing
facilities as required by the improvement. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-14: SERVICE ENTRANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Terms Defined And Described:
      1.   The service entrance equipment, in the case of an overhead service
connection, will include some or all of the following items: a service head, a
service run, fused and not fused disconnecting means, a meter connection
device, an instrument transformer cabinet and an approved grounding connection.
      2.   The service entrance equipment, in the case of an underground
service connection, will include some or all of the following items: a meter
connection device, fused and not fused disconnecting means, an instrument
transformer cabinet, a service run and an approved grounding connection.
      3.   A service head is an approved weather-tight fitting attached to the
free end of a service run and is used to prevent water from entering the
service run.
      4.   A service run consists of a rigid (steel, IMC or aluminum) metal
conduit with enclosed service conductors and shall include all the necessary
hardware from the point of connection to the Utility to the main service panel.
      5.   A meter connection device is an approved device which provides a
means for the Utility to connect a meter to measure electric consumption.
      6.   An instrument transformer cabinet consists of a metal enclosure, a
copper assembly suitable for the installation of instrument transformers,
supports for the copper assembly, cables and color-coded conductors.
      7.   A fused disconnecting means is an approved device used to disconnect
all conductors except the grounded neutral conductors from the source of supply
and provided with appropriate over-current protection.
      8.   A ground connection consists of a conductor and clamps which are
used to connect all metallic enclosures of an electrical installation and the
neutral conductor to a permanent ground. Where available, a ground connection
must be made to the incoming metallic water pipe on the house-side of the water
meter with a continuous suitably sized jumper to the street-side of the water
meter. Where a water pipe is not available, a grounding electrode shall be
installed in conformance with the standards set by the latest available issue
of the National Electric Code (N.E.C.) as published by the National Fire
Protection Association.
   B.   All residential customers with more than six (6) meter sockets shall be
required to install an externally operable fused main disconnect switch which
can be used to disconnect all services from the incoming Utility lines. Such a
switch shall have provisions for the installation of a lock supplied by the
Utility in order to prevent unauthorized operation. Provisions shall be made to
permit the customer to operate the main disconnect in the event of emergency.
   C.   If in a multiple-occupancy building, there is a mixture of residential
and commercial/industrial customers, an externally operable, fused main
disconnect switch shall be required which can be used to disconnect all
services from the incoming Utility lines. Such a switch shall contain
provisions for the installation of a lock supplied by the Utility in order to
prevent unauthorized operation. Provisions shall be made to permit the customer
to operate the main disconnect in the event of an emergency.
   D.   All industrial or commercial customers shall be required to install a
fused main disconnect switch which can be used to disconnect the customer's
service from the incoming Utility lines. Such a switch shall contain provisions
for the installation of a lock supplied by the Utility in order to prevent
unauthorized operation. Provisions shall be made to permit the customer to
operate the main disconnect in the event of an emergency.
   E.   The location for the installation of a meter socket shall be determined
by the Utility as determined by any or all of the following conditions:
      1.   Meter must be placed outside the customer's building in a location
which shall be readily accessible to Utility personnel.
         a.   Customer meter sockets shall not be placed on unattached garages
or other nearby structures.
         b.   Customer meter sockets shall not be placed within fenced in back
yards without the approval of the Utility.
         c.   Customer meter sockets shall not be placed where access is only
available by the use of stairs without the approval of the Utility.
         d.   Customer meter sockets shall not be placed where it is not
possible to read and service meter without the use of step-ladders or other
aids.
         e.   Customer meter sockets shall not be placed inside screened in
porches or over decks.
      2.   Customer meter sockets shall be placed where most readily accessible
from the Utility's distribution facilities.
         a.   Locations which necessitate the crossing of sidewalks or
driveways with the service wires by the Utility shall be avoided where
possible.
         b.   Locations which necessitate the use of more than one hundred
twenty five feet (125') of overhead-type service conductor or one hundred feet
(100') of underground-type service conductor shall be avoided.
      3.   Customer meter sockets shall not be placed near gas facilities.
         a.   Meter sockets shall not be placed over a gas meter.
         b.   Meter sockets shall maintain a minimum of ten feet (10') from any
gas facilities.
      4.   For buildings with two (2) or more meter sockets, all the meters
shall be grouped together in a common area accessible to Utility personnel.
   F.   In all cases, the service run (for overhead-type services only) and the
meter connection device must be installed entirely on the outside of the
building to be served.
   G.   The customer shall furnish, install, own and maintain all service
entrance equipment with the exception of the meter. The Utility will supply
potential and current transformers where required.
   H.   The conductors and conduit of the service entrance equipment shall be
continuous (i.e., conductors not spliced; the conduit system electrically and
mechanically continuous) on the line side of the meter connection device.
   I.   Weather-tight fittings shall be used, specifically, in connecting a
service run to an outdoor meter connection and; generally, where any part of
the service entrance equipment is exposed to the weather.
   J.   All overhead service runs shall be equipped with service heads.
   K.   Metered and unmetered wires shall not be installed within the same
conduit.
   L.   Aluminum conductors shall not be used within a service run or within a
meter connection device unless terminated by suitable compression-type
connectors.
   M.   All service run conductors shall be sized per the requirements and
standards as set by the National Electric Code. In no case, however, can the
service entrance equipment be smaller than that considered as a "standard
service" for the purposes of this Article. The Utility assumes no
responsibility for the adequacy, safety or satisfactory performance of a
customer's service entrance equipment.
   N.   The grounded neutral conductor of the service entrance equipment shall
be identified in such a way as to be readily distinguishable.
   O.   The conductor for the phase having the highest voltage on a three-phase
four-wire Delta installation shall be placed at the center of the three-phase
conductors within the service entrance equipment and shall be identified in
such a way as to be readily distinguishable from the other conductors.
   P.   For services utilizing self-contained meters each ungrounded service
entrance conductor more than a nominal five feet (5') beyond the meter
connection device shall be provided with over-current protection. Such
protection shall be provided by an over-current device in series with each
ungrounded service conductor having a rating or setting not higher than the
allowable ampacity of the conductor.
   Q.   For services not utilizing self-contained meters, each ungrounded
service entrance conductor beyond five feet (5') of the point where the service
enters the building shall be provided with over-current protection.
      1.   Such protection shall be provided by an over-current device in
series with each ungrounded service conductor having a rating or setting not
higher than the allowable ampacity of the conductor.
      2.   For the purpose of this Article, a service is considered to have
entered a building as soon as it penetrates the plane of any exterior wall.
   R.   No over-current device shall be inserted in series with a grounded
service conductor except a circuit breaker that simultaneously opens all
conductors from a circuit.
   S.   If located outdoors, the disconnecting means shall be either of
weatherproof construction or mounted inside a weatherproof box and shall have
provisions for the installation of a lock supplied by the Utility in order to
prevent unauthorized operation. Provisions shall be made to permit the customer
to operate the main disconnect in the event of an emergency.
   T.   If the disconnecting means are installed within a building, the
disconnecting means shall be located within a nominal five feet (5') of the
point where the secondary conductors enter the building and shall be provided
with a shunt-trip mechanism which permits opening of the disconnecting means
from the exterior of the building. This shunt-trip mechanism shall have
provisions for the installation of a lock supplied by the Utility in order to
prevent unauthorized operation. Provisions shall be made to permit the customer
to operate the shunt-trip device in the event of an emergency.
   U.   In all cases, the disconnecting means shall be installed in locations
which permit unobstructed access to Utility personnel.
      1.   No service equipment shall be placed within ten feet (10') of a gas
service meter or regulator.
      2.   No service equipment shall be placed where it would be subject to
excessive heat, moisture, dust or damage from external agents. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-15: GROUNDING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   All metal conduit cabinets, other enclosures and the neutral or
grounded phase conductor shall be permanently grounded by means of an approved
ground connection as defined in subsection
8-1B-14A8 of this Article.
   B.   The following grounding installations shall be provided in accordance
with article 250 of the National Electric Code:
      1.   Systems, circuits and equipment required, permitted or not permitted
to be grounded.
      2.   Circuit conductor to be grounded on grounded systems.
      3.   Location of grounding connections.
      4.   Types and sizes of grounding and bonding conductors and electrodes.
      5.   Methods of grounding and bonding.
      6.   Conditions under which guards, isolation or insulation may be
substituted for grounding.
      7.   Connection of lightning arresters. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-16: METERING:
8-1B-16-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Metering equipment which will be provided by the Utility consists of
such of the following items as are required for the particular installation.
These items include watthour meters, demand registers, recording demand
devices, associated relays and devices, and instrument transformers.
   B.   For instrument transformer installations, the customer shall furnish
specifications and prints for the approval of the Utility before any equipment
is purchased and will install same under the provisions of this Article.
   C.   If the voltage of the electricity to be metered is four hundred eighty
(480) volts or less, and the customer's disconnecting means has a rating of two
hundred (200) amperes or less, self-contained metering equipment shall be
installed for all new or upgraded installations.
   D.   For all new installations or metering installations upgraded to provide
additional load where the supply voltage is four hundred eighty (480) volts or
less, and the customer's disconnecting means has a rating in excess of two
hundred (200) amperes, current transformers shall be installed. This provision
shall not apply to a multiple-occupancy building where each customer is
supplied with a service of two hundred (200) amperes or less.
   E.   Where the utilization voltage is higher than four hundred eighty (480)
volts, current and potential transformers shall be installed for all new or
upgraded metering installations.
   F.   A meter-switch-fuse sequence is an installation where the metering
equipment is connected on the supply side of the disconnecting means installed
in conjunction with the meter.
   G.   A switch-fuse-meter sequence is an installation where the metering
equipment is connected on the load side of the disconnecting means installed in
conjunction with the meter.
   H.   A meter-switch-fuse sequence shall be followed where practicable for
all installations where single-phase or three-phase self-contained meters are
used.
   I.   For instrument transformer type installations, the Utility shall be
consulted concerning the proper metering sequence. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-16-2: LOCATION OF METERING EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Metering equipment will consist of instrument transformers, approved
instrument transformer cabinet and appropriate conduit and fittings.
   B.   The customer shall provide a suitable place on his premises for the
installation of metering equipment. The equipment shall be so located that
adequate space and unobstructed access are provided for the purposes of
reading, testing, inspecting and exchanging of such equipment by Utility
personnel. The customer shall consult the Utility regarding the proper location
of the equipment.
   C.   The metering equipment location shall be free from moisture, but when a
damp location is unavoidable, the customer shall furnish and install, at his
own expense, a moisture-proof cabinet to contain the metering equipment.
   D.   Metering equipment shall not be placed underneath water pipes or
similar objects.
   E.   Metering equipment shall not be placed near a gas service entrance, gas
regulator or gas appliance of any type.
   F.   If there is a possibility that the metering equipment may be exposed to
excessive dust, metal filings or similar substances, the customer shall furnish
and install, at his own expense, a suitable dust-proof enclosure to protect the
equipment.
   G.   Metering equipment shall not be located where it is not accessible by
permanent stairs. A ladder or fire escape cannot be accepted as a substitute
for stairs.
   H.   Metering equipment may be installed outdoors, subject to the approval
of the Utility, if metering equipment is housed within an approved weather-
tight enclosure.
   I.   The choice for the location of the metering equipment is subject to the
approval of the Utility. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-16-3: METER AND METER CONNECTION DEVICE:
   A.   For new or upgraded single-phase and 3-phase installations, the meter
and meter connection device shall be placed on the outside of a building and
shall be readily accessible to utility personnel. Indoor meters shall be
allowed, with the approval of the utility, under the following circumstances:
      1.   Where there is a large number of meters serving a single building.
      2.   Where using outdoor metering is impractical or inadvisable.
   B.   A meter and meter connection device shall not be installed where it
shall be readily susceptible to damage including mechanical injury due to, but
not limited to, vehicular traffic and vandalism. If such a situation should
arise with an existing service, within thirty (30) days after notification by
the utility, the situation shall be corrected by the customer. Should such
action not be taken, and should the meter sustain damage after this period, for
whatever reason, the customer shall be billed for the cost of repair or
replacement of same.
   C.   A meter and meter connection device shall be installed as near as
practical to the point where the service entrance is attached to a building.
   D.   For large multiple occupancy buildings, such as apartment houses,
meters and meter connection devices may be installed grouped in the basement or
in a mechanical room which is readily accessible to utility personnel at all
times; the location to be subject to the approval of the utility.
   E.   Meter connection devices of an approved type shall be furnished and
installed by the customer.
   F.   Maintenance, repair or replacement of a meter connection device shall
be the responsibility of the customer.
   G.   When metering equipment is installed in a multiple occupancy building,
all meter connection devices shall be labelled, tagged or stenciled in a
permanent manner showing the complete address and location of the area served
by each meter connection device.
   H.   The meter connection device shall be installed in such a manner as to
be plumb and to ensure permanent attachment to a rigid vibration free wall or
structure.
   I.   Metered load conductors shall not pass through adjacent meter
connection devices unless such conductors are an integral part of an approved
prewired multiple position meter socket assembly.
   J.   If meter connection devices are installed in locations not adjacent to
the service entrance, the unmetered feeder conductors shall be installed with a
continuous run of rigid conduit and cable.
   K.   If kilovar metering is required by the applicable rate structure, the
customer shall furnish any additional metering equipment, except meter and
instrument transformers which may be necessary. These items shall be furnished
by the utility.
   L.   If the meter connection device for an instrument transformer
installation is not adjacent to the instrument transformer cabinet, the
customer shall provide a suitable rigid conduit (not to exceed 50 feet in
length) extending between the instrument transformer cabinet and the meter
connection device. The utility will supply the necessary color coded conductors
and shall perform the wiring of the installation.
   M.   For instrument transformer installations, the utility shall furnish and
install all metering transformers at its expense.
   N.   The potential leads for any instrument transformer installation shall
be connected to the line side of the current transformer leads. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-17: UTILIZATION EQUIPMENT:
   A.   General Provisions:
      1.   In order that the utility may avoid unnecessary delays in providing
adequate and uniform service to its customers, it is recommended that the
customer, prior to purchase, submit to the utility information regarding any
equipment that is thought might cause interference with service to other
customers or require additional facilities for its satisfactory operation.
      2.   For the purposes of this section, "interference" will be defined as
voltage fluctuations of such a magnitude and frequency as to adversely affect
or annoy other customers of the utility.
      3.   Should the existing facilities be inadequate to properly provide for
any additional load contemplated, the customer must apply for an upgraded
service as provided for in section
8-1B-3 of this article.
      4.   The utility reserves the right to inspect and test any equipment
connected to its lines and to require that such equipment be provided with
nameplates showing the voltage, phase, full load current, maximum current,
maximum kilovolt amperes, and such other information as may be necessary to
determine the operating characteristics of the equipment.
      5.   The utility reserves the right to discontinue service to a customer
whose equipment, in the judgment of the utility, causes unacceptable
interference with the service of other customers.
      6.   Whenever, in the judgment of the utility, a motor starting current
is of a magnitude to cause interference to other customers, the customer shall
be required to provide a starting device of a type which will eliminate such
interference.
      7.   Manually operated reduced voltage starting devices shall be so
constructed that they cannot be placed in the running position before passing
through the starting position.
      8.   Undervoltage release starting equipment is recommended for all
motors seven and one-half (71/2) horsepower or larger. The undervoltage release
shall be of a type that will return the starting device to the off position
when the electric supply is interrupted.
   B.   Power Factors:
      1.   Whenever the customer's utilization equipment has characteristics
that produce a low power factor, the utility reserves the right to require the
customer to correct the low power factor, at the time of the customer's maximum
demand, to a value not less than eighty five percent (85%) lagging as measured
at the point of metering.
Effective January 1, 2012, the utility reserves the right to require the
customer to correct the low power factor, at the time of the customer's maximum
demand, to a value not less than ninety percent (90%) lagging as measured at
the point of metering.
      2.   Should the power factor of a customer's utilization equipment fall
below the eighty five percent (85%) level as set above, a sum of one percent
(1%) of the demand charge for each percentage point below eighty five percent
(85%) shall be levied as a penalty.
Effective January 1, 2012, should the power factor of a customer's utilization
equipment fall below the ninety percent (90%) level a sum of one percent (1%)
of the demand charge for each percentage point below ninety percent (90%) shall
be levied as a penalty.
      3.   Should a customer install capacitors on the secondary side of the
utility's transformation facilities to improve the power factor of his
installation, the customer shall provide, at his expense, overvoltage
protection to ensure that such added capacitance can be safely and
automatically disconnected should the secondary voltage rise to unacceptable
levels due to overcorrection of the power factor. (Ord. 10-22, 6-21-2010)
8-1B-18: SERVICE FACILITIES FOR SUBDIVISIONS OR PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENTS:
   A.   Definitions:
   DEVELOPER: A person, partnership, corporation or other organization
developing land for sale, lease or rental and responsible for the installation
of improvements such as streets, sewers, water and electric.
   SUBDIVISION: A subdivision of single-family lots; multi- family development;
commercial development; industrial development; or any combination of these
classifications.
   B.   General:
      1.   This section pertains to electrical facilities necessary to serve
the proposed structures or buildings to be constructed on the land as
developed. These facilities shall normally include switchgear, transformers,
primary distribution lines, secondary distribution lines, street light poles,
street light luminaires, and all appropriate hardware. These facilities shall
herein be referred to as "electrical distribution facilities".
      2.   The utility shall own, operate and maintain the electrical
distribution facilities provided for under this section for any subdivision or
development within the service territory of the utility.
      3.   Streetlights shall be maintained at the expense of the utility. The
number, type and placement of these lights shall be determined by the utility.
   C.   Single-Family And Multi-Family Developments:
      1.   The electrical distribution system in all new subdivisions of this
category shall be installed underground.
      2.   The Utility shall provide electrical distribution facilities of
adequate capacity to within ten feet (10') of the lot line of any new
subdivision or development. (Ord. 82-39)
      3.   Electrical distribution facilities shall be designed, engineered,
and materials therefor ordered by the Utility, and shall be installed by
developer at its own expense.
      4.   All underground residential distribution (URD) shall be installed
and paid for by developer as a condition of approval of any subdivision. The
scope of work includes the following: all wire installation, street lights,
connection of all primary leads to transformers, pedestals, junction boxes,
switches, excavation, laying of conductors and backfilling. All work must be
approved by a Batavia Electric Department (BED) representative prior to any
connections or backfilling or excavations.
         a.   Where joint Illinois Bell Telephone (IBT) - BED system extensions
are required, it shall be the responsibility of the contractor to notify the
IBT engineer forty eight (48) hours in advance of anticipated dates during
which conductor trench and street crossings will be open and available for
installation of conduit and/or telephone cable. The contractor shall be
responsible to see that IBT cable or conduit is in place in the trench or in
street crossings before backfill and/or closure of trench or street crossings.
Any excavation or street crossing which is filled prior to installation of IBT
lines without written authorization from BED will subject contractor to an
order by BED to reopen such trench or crossing to accommodate the IBT
installation.
         b.   General Rules:
            (1)   All work shall be of a permanent nature, unless otherwise
specified by the BED. Work shall be done in a neat, thorough and workmanlike
manner.
            (2)   The contractor shall show proof of satisfactory completion of
previous high voltage URD work. BED has the right to reject or remove any
contractor for just cause, following written notice to said contractor or the
developer.
            (3)   The contractor shall follow the safety rules of O.S.H.A. or
the Batavia Electric Department whichever is more restrictive, in the judgment
of BED.
            (4)   All work must be performed by or under the direct supervision
of experienced, qualified craftsmen. BED shall have the right, following
written notice to the contractor or developer, to effect the removal of any of
the contractor's employees for reasons of behavior or poor workmanship.
            (5)   The contractor shall furnish proof of adequate insurance and
follow all applicable Federal, State and local laws, and ordinances which may
apply.
            (6)   Street Crossings: All street crossings of conductor and/or
cable shall be installed in heavy wall plastic duct (Schedule 40 or heavier),
or rigid metal conduit if so directed by BED, of adequate size to accommodate
conductor. Duct shall extend a minimum of four feet (4') beyond back of curb
line on each side of street. The duct shall be laid at a minimum of thirty six
inches (36") below the final grade level of street curb.
            (7)   Excavation And Backfill:
   (A) Trenching shall be confined to easements approved by BED. Trench to
minimum of one foot (1') off property line. Trenching shall be excavated to a
depth suitable for random lay of conductors, but in no case shall the top of
any electrical conductor be buried at less than thirty six inches (36") below
final established grade line. The leaving of open trenches is discouraged and a
maximum amount of trench to be open at any time prior to BED inspection shall
be determined by BED for each project. Backfill should proceed as rapidly as
possible after inspectors approval. Trenches may be used jointly for conductors
for primary, secondary, street lighting and telephone cable. Property lines are
not to be crossed except in the immediate area of a property corner.
   (B) Backfill shall consist of excavated material, except that it shall not
contain any frozen earth, logs, stumps, rocks or pieces of masonry, nor debris
or earth with a high void content. Other backfill may be specified by BED. The
contractor shall at all times provide ease of access to working area to IBT
when involved in a joint installation.
            (8)   Pad And Enclosure Placement: All pads, vaults, transformers,
modular cans, switches, pedestals, etc., shall be placed within easements. All
doors or openings shall face towards street or, in the case of rear lot
installations, away from the property line to prevent conflict with possible
future placement of fences, etc.
            (9)   Transformers And Bases: Transformers shall be installed on
fiberglass pads. Pads shall be supported on a minimum six inch (6") gravel base
and shall sit level and square. Fiberglass bases shall be set to provide three
inches (3") dimension from top of finished grade up to top of pad. Primary,
secondary and ground connections shall be made by the electrical contractor.
Primary connections should be terminated so as not to allow primary leads to
cross each other. All terminations to be made by or under the direct
supervision of experienced qualified craftsmen. The left terminal shall have U/
G conductor which leads to transformer from left connected to it, and right to
right. All cables are to be tagged at both ends. Transformers shall be properly
fused by contractor in accordance with fuse chart supplied by (BED).
            (10)   Junction Pedestals: All direct bury pedestals shall be
installed so that the top of finished grade is eight inches (8") below the
bottom of pedestal cover. The pedestal base shall always be installed to
provide a true vertical position for the pedestal.
            (11)   Conductor Placement: All high voltage and low voltage
conductor open ends shall be protected by heat shrinkable end caps or immediate
termination for protection against physical damage and moisture. Terminal ends
shall be inspected and cleaned at time of connecting to any terminal or switch.
BED shall be permitted to lay cable in any trench excavated by the contractor
to extend BED facilities to other areas.
            (12)   Streetlights: The contractor shall install streetlight
standards, fixtures and wiring in an efficient and workmanlike manner. Poles
with fixtures may be assembled and wired prior to erection if so desired but
proper precautions must be taken to prevent damage to units during hauling and
erection. Preferred practice is to transport poles and fixtures separately with
installation of fixtures and wiring subsequent to erection of poles.
            (13)   Switches: As deemed necessary by BED for the proper backup,
protection, etc., special enclosed padmount switches may be required. These
switches shall be mounted on concrete or fiberglass bases as specified. These
bases shall be set on a minimum of twelve inches (12") gravel fill. Top surface
of precast base shall be three inches (3") above final grade. All connections
are to be witnessed by a BED representative.
            (14)   Grounding: As deemed necessary by BED, ground rods shall be
required. Complete ground connections from switch terminals, transformer
terminals, lightning arrestors or other equipment as specified shall be made.
            (15)   Inspections: All work performed by the contractor shall be
subject to inspection by the BED, to insure compliance with the specifications
and with good electrical construction practices. All decisions by authorized
BED representatives are final, unless brought to the attention of the Public
Utilities Committee, whose decision is final.
            (16)   Tests: The contractor shall test all high voltage cable for
faults and grounds upon completion of installation with testing equipment. All
testing shall be completed in the presence of authorized BED personnel, who
will approve results found satisfactory. A minimum acceptable resistance to
ground for insulation test shall be twenty five thousand (25,000) ohms, when
hi-potting primary conductor at fifty two thousand (52,000) volts for a minimum
of five (5) minutes.
            (17)   Equipment: The contractor shall be responsible to provide
all equipment necessary for installing and testing of the system including
special tools required by materials peculiar to the City.
            (18)   Material: The City will provide the material to be used by
the contractor in order to maintain the continuity of existing equipment.
Generally, work shall not begin until all material is on hand in the electric
department warehouse.
            (19)   Ownership And Maintenance, Guarantee For Repairs: The City
will assume ownership, by way of a bill of sale, and maintenance of the system
upon completion and acceptance by the City Council. The developer shall be
responsible for the cost of any repairs or replacement for a period of one
year, and shall deposit a bond or letter of credit to guarantee such repair or
replacement, in a form acceptable to the city.
   D.   Commercial And Industrial Development:
      1.   For the purposes of this subsection, the term "electrical
distribution facilities" shall mean and include such items as are necessary to
provide what is normally considered as primary distribution (voltages in excess
of 2,400 volts). The facilities necessary to supply such primary distribution
include switchgear, overhead switches, power poles, primary lines, street
lighting (including transformation for same), and all appropriate hardware. No
other transformation or secondary lines shall be included.
      2.   Electrical distribution facilities of adequate capacity and
configurations shall be designed, engineered and installed by the utility and
shall be brought to within ten feet (10') of each lot to be developed.
Developer shall pay the city one-half (1/2) the estimated cost of such
extension as a condition of final plat recordation, or building permit issuance
in those areas which have previously been platted. Any adjustment, if
necessary, shall be paid by the developer, or reimbursed by the city, upon
determination by the city of the actual cost of such extension, so that the
developer ultimately pays one-half (1/2) said actual cost.
      3.   The utility shall provide overhead or underground facilities as
determined by BED. (Ord. 90-31, 6-4-1990)
   E.   Approval By Utility: The developer, after preliminary approval of the
subdivision or development, but prior to final approval by the city council of
the plat for recording purposes, shall submit a copy of the plat to the utility
for comment and for approval. The utility shall review the plat for conformance
to the proposed dedicated easements necessary to install, maintain and operate
the electric distribution system. The utility shall then direct a letter to the
city council indicating its approval or objections concerning easements. (Ord.
82-39)
   F.   Payment Of Costs: The developer, following final plat approval, but
prior to recordation of same, or prior to issuance of building permits in those
areas which have already been platted, shall make satisfactory arrangements
with the city for payment of all costs relating to the installation of the
electrical facilities, as determined by the terms of this article. (Ord. 90-31,
6-4-1990)
   G.   Site Preparation: The developer shall, prior to the starting of the
physical installation of the electric distribution facilities, provide the
following:
      1.   Removal of all obstructions from electrical utility easements.
      2.   Placement of marked stakes for lot corners.
      3.   Establishment of, and easement strip clearance to within plus or
minus three inches (±3") of final grade.
      4.   Written notification to utility of completion of subsections G1
through G3 of this section.
   H.   Ownership Of Facilities: All facilities furnished and installed in
conjunction with the subdivision or development shall become and remain the
property of the utility. It shall be the policy of the utility that the
facilities will not be energized, nor any part thereof, until the developer's
proportionate share of the costs of the improvements has been paid to the
municipal utility. (Ord. 82-39)
8-1B-19: INTERCONNECTING RENEWABLE GENERATION FACILITIES TO ELECTRIC UTILITY
GRID:
   A.   Definition: A "renewable generation facility" shall be defined as a
customer- owned photovoltaic system, small wind turbine and/ or renewable
energy battery storage system physically located at the customer' s premises
that is connected to the City's electric distribution system in a manner that
will allow excess electricity generated by the facility to be safely delivered
onto the City's electric distribution system.
   B.   Eligibility: Only customer- owned renewable generating facilities that
have been approved by the Director of Public Works, and/ or his/her designee,
shall be interconnected with the City' s electric distribution system.
   C.   Codes/Regulations: All interconnections shall comply with local, state
and federal codes and regulations including, but not limited to, the National
Electrical Code (NEC), National Electrical Safety Code (NESC), Institute of
Electrical and Electronics Engineers IEEE), and Underwriters Laboratories (UL)
as they may be amended from time to time.
   D.   Interconnection Agreement: The terms and conditions for any and all
interconnections shall be as set forth in the City's Customer-Owned Renewable
Generation Facilities Interconnection Agreement, which may be reasonably
adapted by City staff from time to time. (Ord. 05-46, 10-3-2005; amd. Ord. 16-
40, 7-18-2016; Ord. 20-46. 8-17-2020; Ord. 20-76, 12-21-2020; Ord. 22-13, 3-7-
2022)

WATERWORKS SYSTEM
